Greetings from the Tumaini B SHG Group in Western Kenya! Henry is the facilitator of the group. This group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Henry takes care of 14 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund due to the low prices offered by the firm and in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds to ensure food security for his family. In the recent 2011 season, Henry had a very good maize yield harvesting six bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Henry was only able to harvest one bag of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Henry and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs such as fertilizer and seed is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which also includes training, credit, and insurance. 

With the income from maize sales, Henry will educate his children and repay his loan with the same. 

In 2012, the members of Tumaini B SHG group will each plant between one half and one acre of maize. 

He is pictured with his group members in the photograph above.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Fifatin Group

texts.fr: Le groupe FIFATIN est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la première fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante du groupe, du nom de Charlotte est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Charlotte n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Charlotte est mariée à un certain Saliou. Le couple a un enfant scolarisé et à leur charge. Charlotte vit ensemble avec son mari et son enfant. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Afin de contribuer aux diverses charges de la famille, Charlotte vend depuis cinq ans, des cartes de recharge téléphonique dans un quartier du Bénin. Parallèlement à cette activité, Charlotte vend des produits de mercerie. Charlotte s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu,  Charlotte sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe FIFATIN, un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en:
The group FIFATIN is comprised of three persons who reside in the same district. This is the first time this group has requested financial aid from ALIDé to boost their business. The group's representative, named Charlotte, is the one in the photo with her hand raised. She did not attend school. She is married to a man named Saliou. They have one child in school to support. Charlotte lives together with her husband and child, and they jointly ensure that family expenses are covered. 

To help cover the diverse expenses, Charlotte has been selling phone recharge cards for five years in a district in Benin. Concurrent to this business, she sells sewing supplies. Her supplies come from a market in Benin. 

Seeking to satisfy her customers and to increase her sales and revenues, Charlotte and the other members of the group FIFATIN are requesting an initial loan from ALIDé.

loans.use: to buy phone recharge cards and sewing supplies

loans.name: 030708-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh Hoang Hoa Group

texts.en:
Mrs Nhuận operates a food stall selling fish. She is requesting a loan to purchase fish to resell.

Nhuận is 38 years old, and she is married with two children. She is the leader of an eight-member group, the 030708-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh solidarity group.  She lives and works in Hoang Hoa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with two dependents.

In 2010, Nhuận joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Nhuận has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Nhuận has been involved in this business for more than 10 years. The main hardship that Nhuận faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Nhuận hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to maintain a successful business, and for her business to do well.

loans.use: to purchase fish to resell.

loans.name: Zeinab

texts.en:
Zeinab is a 24-year-old married woman and the mother of a beautiful baby boy. Zeinab is a hard worker, insisting on helping her husband provide for the family by opening a grocery store four years ago. This store has greatly helped in improving their living conditions.

Zeinab is applying for a loan for the first time from Kiva's partner, Al Majmoua, in order to increase her business merchandise with special goods requested for the winter season. Zeinab is a motivated person who is planning to expand her business to reach the level of a supermarket capable of replying to customers' requests from one place.

loans.use: To increase her merchandise with special goods for the winter season

loans.name: Upendo B Group

texts.en:
Judith is the facilitator of the Upendo B group. Judith and her group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

She takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to ensure food security for her family and educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Judith had an excellent maize yield harvesting nine bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, she was only able to harvest two bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Judith and her group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs such as fertilizer and seed is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which also includes training, credit, and insurance. 

With the income from maize sales, Judith will educate her children and build a house.

In 2012, the members of Upendo B group will each plant maize between one half and one acre of land.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Dionicio

texts.en:
Dionicio has operated his rice farming business for almost 38 years. Though he didn't finish his education, he is still proud because he is a good farmer. He is 58 years old, and settled into marriage at a young age. He is grateful because he is blessed with four children, and he spends his income on them. 

Dionicio's wife is a business woman because she is running her variety store. The couple is aiming to obtain plentiful harvest this next cropping season because his rice crops were destroyed by a typhoon last October. He needs to improve his rice fields so that he can gain greater profits to earn a living. Dionicio can't make his dreams come true nowadays because he suffered from the shortage of income, so he is requesting for a loan amount of PHP 25,000. This amount would really help him in making the land more productive by providing the necessary farm inputs. He will be using his loan request to buy hybrid seeds, insecticides, fertilizer, and some amount will be use to pay for the labor cost of transplanting and sowing rice crops for his farm land. He would be glad if his request would be approved.

loans.use: to buy hybrid seeds, insecticides, fertilizer; some amount will be use to pay for the labor cost of transplanting and sowing of the rice crop to his farmland.

loans.name: 030705-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Mrs Bình works in agriculture farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby livestock to raise to sell in the future.

Bình is 50 years old; she is married with four children. She is the leader of a four-member group, the 030705-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group.  She lives and works in Hoằng Hóa district, a  rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with two dependents.

In 2010, Bình joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her  business. Bình has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. Bình has been involved in this business for five years. The main hardship that Bình faces in her business is the lack of capital.

In the future, Bình hopes to buy land of her own, to make enough money to provide for her kids, and to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise to sell in the future.

loans.name: Anita

texts.en:
Anita, 50, is a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Jose, a checker, and they have three children. She and her family manage their household while operating their business. Anita works hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses.

Anita operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil or an egg. Anita earns an income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 500 PHP in daily sales.

To help her continue operations of her business, Anita is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan, which she will use to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Anita hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Nonvignon Group

texts.fr: Le groupe NONVIGNON est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la troisième  fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Rose  est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Rose est âgée de 43 ans et vit au Bénin. Rose  n’a jamais fréquenté. Rose est mariée à un revendeur du nom de Romain. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés dont quatre restent  à leur charge. Rose vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Afin de contribuer aux charges de la famille, Rose vend depuis sept ans, des chaussures dans un quartier du Bénin. Rose s’approvisionne dans un marché au Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Rose sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe NONVIGNON, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les deux premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The NONVIGNON group is made up of three people who live in the same area. It's the third time that the group is asking for financial support from Alidé, in order to elevate their activity level. The representative of the group, named Rose, is the one with her hand raised in the photo. Rose is forty-three years old and lives in Benin. Rose never attended school. Rose is married to a retailer named Romain. The couple has five children, all in school, of which four are in their care. Rose lives with her husband and children. The couple takes care of the expenses of their family together. In order to contribute to the family's expenses, Rose has sold shoes in an area of Benin for seven years. Rose stocks up in a market in Benin. In the mission of satisfying her customers and to increase her turnover and profit, Rose is asking together with the other members of the NONVIGNON group for a third loan from Alidé. The first two loans were completely repaid.

loans.use: to buy bags of shoes.

loans.name: 030706-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Mrs Ngoãn, age 39, raises poultry and cattle to earn a living. She has been involved in this business for three years. She is requesting a loan in order to purchase chicks to raise and sell in future. She and her husband have two children. She is the leader of a seven-member group, the 030706-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group. She lives and works in Hoằng Hóa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2010, Ngoãn joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Ngoãn has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. The main hardship that Ngoãn faces in her business is lack of capital.

In the future, Ngoãn hopes for her business to do well, to be able to buy more supplies and equipment for her business, and to make enough money to provide for her kids.

loans.use: to purchase chicks to raise and sell

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
This is Imelda, 47, a resident of Manila, Philippines. She is married to Noel, a baker, and they have four children. She and her family manage their household while operating their business. Imelda works hard to continually provide income for the family's everyday expenses.

Imelda operates a variety store which, in the Philippines, is basically a small convenience store which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, PHP 5 worth of cooking oil or an egg. Imelda earns an income by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house and her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 1,000 PHP in daily sales.

To help her continue operations of her business, Imelda is requesting a PHP 50,000 loan, which she will use to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.

Imelda hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams of being able to give her family a good future through all her hard work. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members weekly to share stories of her work and to draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Leila

texts.en:
Leila is a 40-year-old married woman with two children, 10 and 13 years old, both in school. She has operated a business selling charcoal in Buluk, South Sudan for one year.

Leila has requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay for her children to go to school.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for resale.

loans.name: 030701-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Mrs Xuân, a 48-year-old married mother of three children, works in agriculture, raising poultry and cattle for the past five years. The leader of a four-member group, the 030701-Đông Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group, Xuân lives and works in Hoằng Hóa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa Province.

The main hardship that Xuân faces in her enterprise is a lack of capital. In 2010, she joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Having repaid her two previous loans, she is requesting a new one to purchase baby livestock to raise for sale.

In the future, Xuân hopes to remodel her house, buy more supplies and equipment for her business, and earn enough money to provide for her children.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise to sell in the future.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.en:
This is Ruth, 46, a resident of Manila in the Philippines. She is married to Jessie, a welder, and a mother to her two children. She, together with her husband and children, manage their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses. 

Ruth operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, five pesos-worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns money by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 300 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day. 

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting an 11,000 PHP loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Ruth hopes to be able to expand soon, just as she dreams to be able to give her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

*All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Microfinance loans.

loans.use: To pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Egnon Group

texts.fr: Le groupe EGNON est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la première  fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. Le représentant du groupe, du nom de Guillaume est celui qui a la main levée sur la photo. Guillaume est âgé de 36 ans et vit au Bénin. Guillaume a arrêté l’école au niveau secondaire. Guillaume est célibataire. Afin de subvenir à ses diverses charges, Guillaume vend depuis une dizaine d’années, des vêtements de façon ambulante. Guillaume désire agrandir et diversifier son activité par la vente de tissus et de produits de mercerie. Guillaume s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Guillaume sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe EGNON, un premier crédit auprès de ALIDé.
texts.en: The EGNON group is made up of three people who live in the same area. It's the first time that the group is asking for financial assistance from Alidé, in order to increase their activity levels. The representative of the group, named Guillaume, est the one with his hand raised in the photo. Guillaume is thirty-six years old and lives in Benin. Guillaume stopped school at the secondary level. Guillaume is single. In order to meet his various expenses, Guillaume has sold clothing on a traveling basis for around a dozen years. Guillaume wants to increase and diversify his activity with the sales of fabrics and notions. Guillaume stocks up in a market in Benin. With the goal of the satisfaction of his customers and to increase his turnover and his profits, Guillaume is asking for a first loan from Alidé, together with the other members of the EGNON group.

loans.use: to buy fabrics and notions.

loans.name: 030812-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Mrs Hoa, age 31, raises poultry and cattle. She has been engaged in this business for six years. Her primary business challenge is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby livestock to raise and to sell in future. 

Mrs Hoa is the leader of a four-member group, the 030812-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group. She lives and works in Hoằng Hóa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province, with her husband and two children.

In 2010, Hoa joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Hoa has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women.

In the future, Hoa hopes for her business to do well, to make enough money to provide for her children, and to maintain a successful business.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to roads and sell

loans.name: Aigul

texts.ru: Айгуль 48 лет, замужем.  Имеет троих детей – школьников. Основная деятельность семьи Айгуль – это откорм и перепродажа скота.  Начатое еще в 1991 году со  стартовой суммой в 5,000 сом (KGS) хозяйство сегодня приносит около 4,000 сом (KGS) в месяц.   В данный момент, в хозяйстве Айгуль имеется две дойной коровы и пять баранов. В целях дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Айгуль обратилась в компанию «Бай  Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) на покупку дополнительного скота. Это позволит ей увеличить своей хозяйство и приумножить поголовье скота, сделав, таким образом по ее мнению, наилучшее капиталовложение.
texts.en: Aigul is 48 years old, married and has three school-age children.  Aigul's family's primary business is fattening up and reselling livestock.  This business was started in 1991 with an initial sum of 5,000 som (KGS) and now yields about 4,000 som (KGS) per month.  Currently, Aigul has two dairy cows and five sheep.  In order to further increase livestock headcount, she requested a loan in the sum of 50,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company for the purchase of additional livestock.  This will help her expand her business and increase livestock headcount; thus, making a good capital investment.

loans.use: to purchase additional livestock

loans.name: Jesukpego Group

texts.fr: Le groupe JESUKPEGO est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Hélène est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Hélène est âgée de 35 ans et vit au Bénin. Hélène n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Hélène est mariée à un soudeur du nom de Clément. Le couple a quatre enfants tous scolarisés et  à leur charge. Hélène vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Afin de contribuer aux diverses charges de la famille,  Hélène vend depuis cinq ans, des nappes de table et des ustensiles de cuisine de façon ambulante. Hélène s’approvisionne au Togo. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu,  Hélène sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe JESUKPEGO, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le premier prêt a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
The JESUKPEGO group is composed of three people who live in the same neighborhood. This is their second time seeking financial support from ALIDé to bolster their activities. The representative of the group is Hélène, seen with her hand raised in the photo. 

Hélène is 35 years old and she lives in Benin. She never attended school. She is married to a welder named Clement and they have four dependent children, all in school. Hélène lives with her husband and their children and the couple provide together for the family’s needs. 

In order to help with the various household responsibilities, Hélène started selling tablecloths and kitchen utensils door to door five years ago. She buys her merchandise in Togo. 

Eager to meet the needs of her customers and increase her sales and revenue, Hélène is seeking a second loan from ALIDé together with the other members of the JESUKPEGO group. The first loan was correctly repaid.

loans.use: to buy tablecloths and kitchen utensils for resale

loans.name: Nasinani Group

texts.en:
Thomas is the facilitator of the Nasinani group. Thomas and his group joined One Acre Fund in 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program. 

Thomas takes care of six children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access fertilizer and hybrid seed. In the recent 2011 season, Thomas had a very good maize yield harvesting nine bags on half an acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Thomas was only able to harvest three bags of maize on that land. 

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Thomas and his group during Kenya's next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs such as fertilizer and seed is part of One Acre Fund's integrated agriculture package, which also includes training, credit, and insurance. 

With the income from maize sales, Thomas will educate his children, build a house, and invest in livestock rearing. 

In 2012, the members of Nasinani group will each plant maize plots between one half and one acre of land. 

In the photograph above, Thomas is pictured with his group members and the field officer is at the far left.

loans.use: To buy farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Schekina-Power Group

texts.fr: Le groupe SCHEKINA-POWER est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la cinquième  fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Cica est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Cica est âgée de 46 ans et vit au Bénin. Cica  n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Cica est mariée à un certain Benoît. Le couple a cinq enfants tous scolarisés dont trois restent encore à leur charge. Cica vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Afin de contribuer aux diverses charges de la famille, Cica vend depuis huit ans, du maïs, de l’haricot, et du pain dans un quartier du Bénin. Cica s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Cica sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe SCHEKINA-POWER, un cinquième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les quatre premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The Schekina-Power group is made up of three people who live in the same quarter. This is the fifth time that the group has sought a loan from ALIDé, in order to boost their business. The group's leader, Cica, has her hand raised in the photo. She is 46 years old, lives in the Benin and is married to Benoît. She did not attend school. The couple has five children, all of whom attend school, and three of whom are in the couple's care. Cica lives with her husband and children. The couple look after the family's needs together. In order to see to the family's needs, for the past eight years Cica has sold corn, beans and bread in a quarter of the Benin. She sources her goods from a market in the Benin. In order to satisfy her clients and to boost her revenue, she and the other members of the Schekina-Power group are seeking a fifth loan from ALIDé. The previous four loans have been successfully repaid.

loans.use: to purchase bags of corn, beans and bread

loans.name: Susan

texts.en:
This is Susan, 58, resident of Manila, Philippines. Single, she manages her own household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses 

Susan operates a fruit stand. She buys seasonal fruits that are native to the Philippines like bananas, which are grown mostly in the southern region of Luzon. She also sells other Filipino fruit staples. Aside from this, she also cooks and caters food for additional income. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community.  She earns a minimum of Php 1000 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 15,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy more quantities of fruit to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Susan dreams of growing her business in the coming years. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional stocks of fruit needed in her business.

loans.name: 030808-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Mrs Tuyết, age 37, has a retail business where she sells books, textbooks, and student supplies. She has been involved in her business for over 10 years. Her primary business challenge is lack of capital. She is requesting a loan to purchase additional student supplies to offer for sale.

She is the leader of a three-member group, the 030808-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group. She lives and works in Hoằng Hóa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province. She and her husband have two children.

In 2010, Tuyết joined Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women to improve her business. Tuyết has successfully repaid two loans from Thanh Hoa Fund for Poor Women. In the future, she hopes to buy land of her own, to maintain a successful business, and to see her business do well.

loans.use: to purchase student supplies to offer for sale

loans.name: Amba C Group

texts.en:
Irine is the facilitator of the Amba C group. Anne and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Irine and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

Irine takes care of four children at home with her husband. She joined One Acre Fund due to One Acre Fund’s affordable input prices.In the recent 2011 season, Anne had an excellent maize yield, harvesting 18 bags on 1 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Irine was only able to harvest 6 bags of maize on 1  acre of land.

With income from maize sales, Irine will pay for major yearly expenses, such as school fees and livestock investments.

In 2012, the members of Amba C group will each plant maize plots of between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Irine is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
Anna is a 40-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of 20 to 10 years. Three of them are in school. She has had a business selling charcoal in Buluk, South Sudan for two years.

Anna requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. she will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Mukhran

texts.en:
Mukhran, 32, lives with his retired parents in the village of Gomi, in West Georgia, where he conducts the family's farming activities. They own three milk cows from which his mother produces and sells an average of 40 kg of cheese per month. On the family-owned 2-hectare plot of land, Mukhran grows maize, about 60% of which is sold, while the remainder is used to feed the cows. Mukhran also owns an old tractor with which he does seasonal agricultural work, earning about 200 Laris per month in tilling seasons. The family's total average monthly income is 510 Laris, including his parents’ pensions

Mukhran is now requesting a loan to purchase new wheels for his tractor. As soon as he replaces the old wheels, he will be able to reengage in his work. He plans to save earned income to purchase furniture for the house, as the family currently has very little.

loans.use: to purchase wheels for his tractor.

loans.name: Munkhtuya

texts.en:
Munkhtuya is a 34-year-old married entrepreneur who lives with her son and spouse in an outer ger district without basic infrastructure in Ulaanbaatar, Mongolia. She supports her family by operating her own car oil sales business at the local largest outdoor technical market. Sometimes her husband helps her operate the business and their son attends secondary school. 

Munkhtuya's son is a five-point pupil and his parents desire to make better living conditions for the family. Munkhtuya’s old house was very small and not cozy for the family, so they built a new house which isn’t yet finished. Since the temperature falls below -40C during the winter in Ulaanbaatar, Munkhtuya wants to make her new house warm and cozy.

Munkhtuya is requesting a 3.000.000 MNT loan to purchase the necessary recovery materials, such as bricks and cement, for her new house.

loans.use: to purchase necessary construction materials for her new house.

loans.name: Oyunsuren

texts.en: Oyunsuren is 59 years old and lives with her son and grandson in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Uvurhangai province, Mongolia. Oyunsuren operates a shoe-making business. She started her business in 2010 by taking training from Mercy Corp. Since then, her business has been going so well that she can't meet her customers' demands. She is therefore requesting a 1,000,000 MNT loan to buy supplies and tools. Oyunsuren is a hardworking and diligent woman who says, "My father used to make shoes. When he was alive, I wasn't old enough to pick up his skills. Now that I have, I'm really glad".

loans.use: To buy supplies and tools

loans.name: Tessie

texts.en:
Tessie's primary source of income is rice farming. She is 54 years old and is widowed. She plants and harvests rice from her two-hectare field. Last season, Tessie did not have a good harvest due to a typhoon that affected her area. She felt sad about what happened to her crops, but she was determined to meet the needs of her children. Now she hopes to improve her crop to produce an abundant harvest.      

Tessie is asking for a loan of PHP 25,000 to acquire herbicides and pesticides (chemicals used to control weeds and pests that affect seedling growth) to use in farming. She wants to ensure good growth of her seedlings. Tessie would like to continue receiving loans to help expand her business and to generate profits to invest in the future.

loans.use: to acquire herbicides and pesticides for farming.

loans.name: Nonvigbe1 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe NONVIGBE1 est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la troisième  fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Biwègnon Hervée  est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Biwègnon Hervée est âgée de 34 ans et vit au Bénin. Biwègnon Hervée a arrêté l’école au niveau universitaire. Biwègnon Hervée est mariée à un journaliste du nom de Péguy Sudovic. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Biwègnon Hervée vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Afin de contribuer aux diverses charges de la famille, Biwègnon Hervée vend depuis huit ans, des tenues vestimentaires dans un quartier du Bénin. Parallèlement à cette activité, Biwègnon Hervée  vend des chaussures. Biwègnon Hervée s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu ,  Biwègnon Hervée sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe NONVIGBE1, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les deux premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The NONVIGBE1 group is made up of three people who live in the same quarter. This is the third time the group has sought financial aid from ALIDé, in order to boost their business. The group's leader, Biwègnon Hervée has her hand raised in the photo; she is 34 years old and lives in the Benin. Biwègnon Hervée left school at university level. She is married to a journalist called Péguy Sudovic with whom she has two children who attend school. The couple see to the family's needs together. In order to contribute to the family's needs, Biwègnon Hervée has sold clothes for a living for eight years from a quarter in the Benin. In order to meet her customers' demands and to boost business, Biwègnon Hervée  and the other members of the NONVIGBE1 group are seeking a third loan from ALIDé. The two previous loans have been successfully repaid.

loans.use: to purchase shoes and clothes

loans.name: Doung

texts.en:
Mrs. Doung is a diligent and responsible housewife who lives in the Baray district of Kompong Cham province. She cultivates rice during the rainy season and also raises hogs. She typically earns a profit of $4.00 per day from her hog-raising business. She’s very hardworking in order to support her children’s education. She wants them to finish high school.

Doung is taking out this loan to repair her plowing machine because it’s necessary for her farming business this year. In the future, she intends to open a small grocery store in the neighborhood to start serving meals, drinks and some types of Khmer traditional liquor (fermented sugar palm juice).

loans.use: to repair her plowing machine.

loans.name: Nonvignon2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe NONVIGNON2 est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la troisième  fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Rufine est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Rufine est âgée de 32 ans et vit au Bénin. Rufine n'a jamais fréquenté l'école. Rufine est mariée à un boucher du nom de Olivier. Le couple à deux enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Rufine vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Afin de contribuer aux charges de la famille, Rufine vend depuis cinq ans, de l’huile végétale et des conserves dans un quartier du Bénin. Rufine s’approvisionne dans un marché au Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu,  Rufine sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe NONVIGNON2, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les deux premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The NONVIGNON2 group is made up of three people who live in the same quarter. This is the third time that the group has sought a loan from ALIDé in order to boost business. The group's leader, Rufine, has her hand raised in the photo. She is 32 years old and lives in the Benin. Rufine has never attended school. She is married to a butcher called Olivier with whom she has two children who attend school. Rufine lives with her husband and children, and the couple work together to see to their family's needs. In order to see to the family's needs, Rufine has sold vegetable oil and canned foods from a quarter in the Benin for the past five years. She sources her goods from the market in the Benin. In order to meet her customers' needs and to boost business Rufine and the other members of the NONVIGNON2 group are seeking a third loan from ALIDé. The first two loans have been successfully repaid.

loans.use: to purchase canned foods and cans of vegetable oil

loans.name: 030807-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Lan has a farm where she raises poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby livestock to raise for sale in the future.

Lan is 34 years old, and she is married with three dependent children. She is the leader of a four-member group, the 030807-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group. She lives and works in Hoằng Hóa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2010, Lan joined Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) to improve her business, and she has successfully repaid two loans from FPW. Lan has been involved in the livestock business for five years. The main hardship that she faces is a lack of capital.

In the future, Lan hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to maintain a successful business, and to buy more supplies and equipment for her business.

loans.use: to purchase baby livestock to raise and sell.

loans.name: Mylene

texts.en:
This is Mylene, 40, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Rogel, her business partner, and a mother to her only child. She, together with her husband, manages their household while operating the business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for her everyday expenses.  

Mylene operates a variety store. In the Philippines, a variety store is basically a small convenience store, which retails groceries, toiletries and beverages piecemeal to the local neighborhood. It is the place to go to buy one sachet of shampoo, a PHP 5 worth of cooking oil, or an egg. She earns by getting supplies at wholesale prices and selling by the piece. Her store is located adjacent to her house. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of Php 500 in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a PHP 10,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy groceries, toiletries, and beverages to expand her product inventory. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Mylene dreams to be able to give all her family a good future through all her hard work on her business. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship* members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies.

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and repay microfinance loans.

loans.use: to pay for grocery items and products needed in her business.

loans.name: Jesukpego2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe JESUKPEGO2 est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la troisième  fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Valérie  est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Valérie est âgée de 36 ans et vit au Bénin. Valérie n’a jamais fréquenté. Valérie est mariée à un menuisier du nom de Dénis. Le couple a trois enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Valérie vit avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Afin de contribuer aux charges de la famille, Valérie vend depuis cinq ans, des charbons de bois et du maïs dans un quartier du Bénin. Valérie s’approvisionne dans un marché au Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu , Valérie sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe JESUKPEGO2, un troisième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les deux premiers prêts ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en: The JESUKPEGO2 group is made up of three people from the same quarter. It is the third time that this group has sought a loan from ALIDé in order to boost their business. The group's leader, Valérie has her hand raised in the photo. She is 36 years old and lives in the Benin. She never went to school. She is married to a carpenter called Dénis. The couple has three children, all of whom attend school. Valérie lives with her husband and children. The couple work together to see to their family's needs. In order to cater for these needs, Valérie has sold coal and corn for a living for the past five years. She sells her goods from a quarter of the Benin and sources them from a local market. In order to satisfy her customers' demand and to boost business, Valérie and the other members of the JESUKPEGO2 group are seeking a third loan from ALIDé. The first two were successfully reimbursed.

loans.use: to purchase bags of coal and corn

loans.name: Davaachuluun

texts.en: Davaachuluun is 52 years old and lives with his wife and son in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Govi-Altai Province, Mongolia. His wife helps with her business, and his son is a college student. He started his meat retailing business in 1995. His business is pretty much the same since then, therefore this year he decided to travel across countryside by himself and buy the livestock himself. He has already done some research and found a number of suppliers. However, due to his financial problems, it is impossible to buy livestock. He is a sharp and hard-working man who says, "It's been tight since my son joined college, so I had to do something to make this right." He is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to buy livestock.

loans.use: to buy livestock

loans.name: Moreen's Group

texts.en:
Moreen's group is comprised of two hard-working women. Moreen is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in the Fort Portal region of Uganda. She is married and has three children with two of them currently in school. For the past six years, Moreen has been working hard to manage her small store, which sells fresh produce, plates, and glass. 

To help expand her business, Moreen has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more matooke (plaintains) and glasses, and will help Moreen to generate greater profits and pay for her children's school fees. Moreen hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Moreen is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Moreen's future prospects by helping her to learn how to save money.

loans.use: to purchase more matooke (plaintains) and glasses

loans.name: Gideon

texts.en: Gideon is married and blessed with three children, all of whom attend school. He describes himself as a hardworking businessman. He has been running a tailoring business for the last ten years to support his family. In the next five years, he wants to expand his business. Gideon is requesting a loan of 25,000 Kenyan shillings to add to his stock of fabric.

loans.use: to add to his stock of fabric.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to purchase boxes of hair extensions and cosmetic products.

loans.name: Zuhura

texts.en:
Zuhura is a 26-year-old married woman with five children, four of whom are enrolled in school while one is too young for school. Her husband Mwarobo, who is employed, also contributes to the provision of the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

Zuhura has operated a retail shop for the past four months; her potential clients are the local area residents. She faces a major challenge of customers not paying their debts in time. She dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale shop in the future.

With the Kshs 15,000 she wants to purchase stocks of beans, maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, and soap for her shop. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of beans, maize flour, wheat flour, sugar, and soap for her shop.

loans.name: Tabita

texts.en:
Tabita is 40-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of 6 and 18. All of them are in school. She has a business of selling food in a  stall in Buluk, South Sudan for two years.

Tabita requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase onions, tomatoes, and breads. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase onions, tomatoes, and breads to sell.

loans.name: Mahutin2 Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MAHUTIN2 est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Christine est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Christine est âgée de 39 ans et vit au Bénin. Christine n’a pas fréquenté l’école. Christine est mariée à un certain Basile. Le couple a trois enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Christine vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille.  Afin de contribuer aux diverses charges de la famille, Christine vend des fruits dans un marché du Bénin. Christine s’approvisionne dans un village du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Christine sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MAHUTIN2, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le premier prêt a été bien remboursé.
texts.en: The Mahutin2 group is composed of three people living in the same neighborhood. This is the second time that the group is seeking financing from ALIDé in order to expand its business. Christine, the group’s representative, is the one raising her hand in the photo. Christine is 39 years old and lives in Benin. Christine is married to a man by the name of Basile. They have three dependent children, all in school. Christine lives together with her husband and children. The spouses jointly provide for family needs. In order to contribute to the family budget, Christine sells fruits at a market in Benin. Christien stocks up in a village in Benin. With the goal of meeting customer demand and increasing her sales volume and her revenues, Christine, together with the other members of the Mahutin2 group, is seeking a second loan from ALIDé. The first loan has been duly repaid.

loans.use: to buy baskets of fruits

loans.name: Beth

texts.en:
Beth is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in Uganda. She is married and has two children, one of whom is currently in school. For the past two years, Beth has been working hard to manage her business making and laying bricks. 

To help expand her business, Beth has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more materials to fire bricks, and will help Beth to generate greater profits and pay for her children's school fees. Beth hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house. 

Beth is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Beth's future prospects by helping her to learn how to save and budget money.

loans.use: to purchase more materials to fire bricks

loans.name: Upendo A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Upendo A group in Western Kenya! Rosemary is the facilitator of the Upendo A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Rosemary takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Rosemary had very good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Rosemary was only able to harvest two bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Rosemary and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Rosemary will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Upendo A group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

In the photograph above, Rosemary is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: 030802-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Huệ has a tailoring business. She is requesting a loan to maintain her tailoring shop.

Huệ is 28 years old, and she is married with two dependent children. She is the leader of a five-member group, the 030802-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group. She lives and works in Hoằng Hóa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2010, Huệ joined the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) to improve her business, and she has successfully repaid two loans from FPW. Huệ has been involved in this business for more than 10 years, and the main hardship that she faces is a lack of capital.

In the future, Huệ hopes to make enough money to provide for her kids, to maintain a successful business, and to buy a new motorbike.

loans.use: to maintain her tailoring shop.

loans.name: Altantsetseg

texts.en:
Mrs. Altantsetseg, 52, is a druggist, a profession that she practiced between 1980 and 1997. Now she works as a social worker in a public organization. She was widowed many years ago and now lives with her two children in the ger district in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. A ger is the traditional Mongolian nomadic tent.
 
Altantsesteg has been thinking about her profession for the last several years. Her current income does not enable her to meet her family's regular expenses. Her two children both attend secondary school, and there are always sudden expenses related to her children. Once she said that one of her biggest wishes is to get the best education for her two children. 

Due to her financial circumstances, she decided to start a pharmacy business in order to increase her earnings. She needs about 2,800,000 MNT initially to build working capital for her new business. The loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchasing drugs from certified suppliers for starting her pharmacy business.

loans.use: To purchase drugs for starting her pharmacy business.

loans.name: Khakosi B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Khakosi B Group in Western Kenya! Alice is the facilitator of the Khakosi B group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Alice takes care of five children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Alice had an excellent maize yield harvesting 11 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Alice was only able to harvest four bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Alice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Alice will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Khakosi B group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Tahmina

texts.ru: Тахмина умная, талантливая и трудолюбивая девушка. Она не замужем. Более двух лет она занимается пошивом национальных платьев. Она шьет и вышивает разные  орнаменты на платьях. Имеет много постоянных клиентов и с радостью обслуживает их. Она берет заказы на дом и у неё хорошие условия для пошива. Она хотела бы получить займ для покупки компьютерной  машинки для вышивки. Она заранее благодарна вам за вашу поддержку и понимание.
texts.en: Tahmina is a smart, talented and hardworking young woman.  She is not married.  She has been involved in sewing national dresses for over two years.  Tahmina sews and embroiders ornaments on dresses.  She has many regular clients and gladly provides the service to them.  She takes her orders at home and has good conditions for sewing there.  Tahmina wants to obtain this loan for the purchase of a computerized embroidery machine.  She is grateful to you in advance for your support and understanding.

loans.use: to purchase a computerized embroidery machine

loans.name: Tumurochir

texts.en: Tumurochir is 27 years old and lives with her husband and daughter in a ger (a Mongolian yurt) in Ulaanbaatar city, Mongolia. She operates a jewely store with the help of her husband. She started her business in 2010 by renting a counter in a market. She's the only one who sells accessories in the market; therefore, it is very profitable. Her products are very limited due to her counter space, so she rented one more counter in the market. She has limited resources to run a whole counter, so she is requesting 1,500,000 MNT to buy more supplies.

loans.use: To buy jewelry for resale

loans.name: Caroline

texts.en:
Caroline is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyenjojo in Uganda. For the past year, Caroline has been working hard to manage her small shop, which sells stationery items. 

To help expand her business, Caroline has requested a loan of 200,000 UGX from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase more pens and paper, and will help Caroline to generate greater profits and improve her family's standard of living. Caroline hopes that in the future she will be able to buy a plot of land and build a house, and to get a driver's license. 

Caroline is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to microfinance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities, and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Caroline's future prospects by helping her to learn how to save and to manage money.

loans.use: to purchase more pens and paper

loans.name: Lucie

texts.en:
Lucie is 24 years old and married with a three-year-old child. She operates a good, well-maintained business selling men's clothing. She has four years' experience in this business. She works from 8 am until 6 pm six days a week.

Lucie has requested a loan from Kiva through Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more assorted men's clothes for resale. With any profits from the loan, Lucie will expand her business and save for her family. She will also be able to pay school fees for her child.

loans.use: to purchase men's clothing for resale.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
This is Elizabeth, 62, a resident of Tanza, Cavite City, Philippines. She is a single parent and a mother to one child. With her child, she manages her household while operating a business. At this time, she is working hard to continually provide income for their everyday expenses.

Elizabeth oversees operations of their tricycle transportation business. She owns one tricycle (motorcycle with sidecar attached to it) that carries four to five passengers to their destination within the community. She earns an income through the boundary (daily quota) that her driver remits each day. Her regular customers are her neighbors in the local community. She earns a minimum of 250 PHP in sales every day. 

To help her continue operating her business, she is requesting a 10,000 PHP loan. She will utilize the loan for additional spare parts and the maintenance of her tricycle. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business.  

Elizabeth hopes to be able to have another tricycle. She faithfully meets up with her co-fellowship members to share stories of her work every week and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners/clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay micro-finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for spare parts and maintenance of her tricycle

loans.name: Ziad

texts.en:
Ziad is a 31-year-old married man and father of one lovely child.  He sells coffee, hot chocolate, and several other hot and cold drinks to his customers. His business is improving, although he has been working in this field for only a year.  Ziad used to work as a driver, but he wanted to improve his living through starting his own business.  He took a courageous step.  Most of his clients encourage him to expand his offerings, and he is taking a step towards expanding by requesting a loan from Kiva partner, Al Majmoua.  

With the loan, he will buy a new espresso machine, which will respond to more customers at the same time.  Ziad has been an Al Majmoua borrower for four consecutive cycles.  He is a borrower in good standing and the loans reflect positively on his social situation.  He hopes to keep expanding his business and his customers' trust.

loans.use: To buy new espresso machine necessary for improving his business

loans.name: 030811-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá Group

texts.en:
Huyền works in agriculture, farming poultry and cattle. She is requesting a loan to purchase baby poultry to raise for sale in the future.

Huyền is 40 years old, and she is married with two dependent children. She is the leader of a six-member group, the 030811-Tây Xuân Vi-Hoằng Thanh-Hoằng Hoá solidarity group. She lives and works in Hoằng Hóa district, a rural area in Thanh Hoa province.

In 2010, Huyền joined the Fund for Thanh Hoa Poor Women (FPW) to improve her business, and she has successfully repaid two loans from FPW. Huyền has been involved in this business for two years, and the main hardship that she faces is a lack of capital.

In the future, Huyền hopes to buy land of her own, to buy more supplies and equipment for her business, and for her family to be healthy and happy.

loans.use: to purchase baby poultry to raise and sell.

loans.name: Vinda

texts.en:
Vinda is a 38 year-old married woman with six children between the ages of 20 and 7 years.   Four of them are in school.  She has had a business of selling charcoal in Buluk, South Sudan, for two years.

Vinda requested this loan through BRAC,  South Sudan, to purchase charcoal.  She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Huantai

texts.en: Huantai is 40 years old and lives with his wife and two sons in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bayan-ulgii province, Mongolia. His wife helps with his business.  His elder child is a college student and the younger one is school student. He started his business in 2010 by purchasing two cows to milk. Now he has 10 cows and produces 20 L's of milk. Now that it's winter season, it's impossible to find natural resources to feed the cows.  He is a sharp and hardworking man who says"I am almost out of supplies, and I need to do everything I can in order to make this right".  Therefore, he is requesting 2,000,000 MNT to buy food for cows.

loans.use: To buy food for cows

loans.name: Tsitsino

texts.en:
Tsitsino is a farmer from the village Kutiri, West Georgia. She is 49 years old and lives with her husband, Nikoloz, and a 31 year-old son and daughter-in-law. Tsitsino and Nikoloz lead the agricultural business of the family. They have 4 milk cows and produce, on average, 70 kg of cheese per month. They sell it at the local market. Also, the family has a pig and sells, on average, 10 piglets per year. Along with the above mentioned, Tsitsino and Nikoloz grow tomatoes, cabbages, peppers and greens on a family-owned plot of land. Tsitsino sells harvested vegetables locally to greengrocery retailers. Her son works in the local hospital as its security service employee and his wife works in the same hospital as a laundress. 

Total average income of the family is 950 Laris per month. Tsitsino plans to purchase an additional milk cow with the loan. Cheese production and sales will be increased by 25%. Tsitsino will use the increased income for covering medical costs related to the treatment of her husband, who has health problems.

loans.use: to purchase a milk cow

loans.name: Violeta

texts.en:
This is Violeta, 55, a resident of Quezon City, Philippines. She is married to Dominador, who is self-employed, and fatherto her children. She and her husband manage their household while operating the business. They work hard to continuously provide their daily needs and expenses.   

Viloeta operates a computer rental shop. In the Philippines, very few people own their own computers. Thus, there is a need for them, especially for students who need to do their research and papers. She rents out computers by the hour and offers printing and typing services. Her regular customers are her neighbors and the local community. She earns a minimum of 800 Philippine Pesos (PHP) in sales every day.

To help her continue operations of her business, she is requesting a Php 9,000 loan. She will be utilizing the loan to buy new computer units, and additional LCD screens needed in her business. She expects a boost in her business income as she expands her business. 

Violeta hopes that her business will last a long time and be inherited by her children. Just like other parents, she dreams that all her children will be able to have a good family life and business. She never fails to attend to the fellowship* every week as it inspires her to grow more spiritually and where she can also draw strength and inspiration from the Word of God she studies. 

* All CCT community partners / clients are organized into fellowship groups that meet on a weekly basis. A fellowship group is composed of 15 to 30 community partners. The fellowship groups gather each week to study the Word of God, build social capital, and pay Micro Finance loans.

loans.use: To pay for additional spare parts and units needed in her business

loans.name: Tsogzolmaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Tsogzolmaa, 26, is unmarried and works as a secretary in a private company. She graduated from college two years ago and now lives with her younger brother in a one-room apartment in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. The apartment, which was built in 1960, came from their parents. 
 
Lately her apartment has become very old and uncomfortable to live in due to some problems and some damage. Therefore, she decided to renovate her apartment. She needs to insulate the windows of her room, because in winter there is heat loss through the windows. She is planning to do this during her holidays before Christmas day. The loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchasing building materials to renovate her apartment.

loans.use: To purchase building materials to renovate her apartment.

loans.name: Julie

texts.en: Julie is 47 years old and lives with his wife and children in the province of Isabela. He has been a farmer for 20 years. Together with his wife, he plants and harvests rice for sale. His business earns PHP 20,000 every harvest season. His wife has also managed their hog-raising business for five years. The most tiresome part is clearing the piggery and taking care of the hogs day after day. They both work hard to meet their family's daily needs and to give their children daily allowances. At this time, Julie is requesting a loan of PHP 35,000 to purchase rice seedlings and fertilizers for his farm. He hopes that he can get the amount he has requested, and he promises to repay the loan on time.

loans.use: to purchase rice seedlings and fertilizers for his farm.

loans.name: Altynai

texts.ru:
Алтынай 46 лет, замужем. Муж Касым занимается скотоводством.  В поисках дополнительного источника дохода для своей семьи, в 1997 году Алтынай начала свой бизнес в торговле овощами и фруктами. Стартовав с суммы 8,000 сом (KGS), Алтынай благодаря настойчивости  и упорному труду,  сумела развить свой бизнес  с ежемесячным доходом  10,000 сом (KGS). Фрукты, такие как мандарины, виноград, хурма она привозит из Таджикистана, также закупает продукцию в виде яблок, помидоров, перца у местных производителей по оптовой цене, затем продает на местном рынке.  
В целях дальнейшего развития своего бизнеса, Алтынай обратилась  в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на расширение ассортимента.  Доходы от кредита Алтынай планирует вложить в  расширение торгового места.
texts.en:
Altynai is a married forty-six year old. Her husband is an animal breeder. 
In 1997, in need of an additional source of income, Altynai began a business selling fruits and vegetables. Altynai had a starting capitol of 8,000 soms (KGS) but, due to her persistence and hard work, she now manages a business with a monthly profit of 10,000 soms (KGS). 
She imports fruits like mandarins, grapes and date-plums from Tajikistan while purchasing apples, tomatoes and peppers from local farmers. This is then sold at the local market. In order to expand her business further, Altynai came to 'Bai Tushum and Partners' for a loan of 100,000 soms (KGS) needed to broaden her assortment of goods. She plans to invest the profits from this loan into expanding her sales point.

loans.use: to broaden an assortment of goods

loans.name: Dulamsuren

texts.en: Dulamsuren is 33 years old and lives with her husband and three children in a ger (Mongolian yurt) in Bayanhongor province, Mongolia. Her husband is a security guard. Her elder two children are school students and the younger one goes to kindergarten. Dulamsuren started her embroidered products retail business in 2008 by renting a counter in a market. Now that her business is stable enough, she wants to expand it by renting another counter. However, she doesn't have enough supplies to support having another counter. Therefore, she's requesting 1,000,000 MNT to buy more supplies.

loans.use: to buy more supplies for her embroidered products retail business.

loans.name: Arlie Group

texts.en:
Arlie is married and has three children. Arlie is 36 years old and lives in the Philippines.

Arlie is a farmer who grows corn to earn a living. She has been doing this for 11 years. She has requested a loan of 14,000 PHP to purchase fertilizer for growing corn. 

Arlie has been a member of PMPC for one year. In the future, Arlie hopes to support her children's education.

Arlie is the leader of a three-person group. Although they borrow as a group, each member of the group has their own business.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizer for growing corn.

loans.name: Urbano

texts.en:
Urbano desires a better quality of life for his family. He patiently strives to work his farm just to feed his children. Urbano is 46 years old and married with four children. He is a farmer, planting rice in their village. He has been in this business for 26 years. He earns approximately PHP 60,000 per crop, and he uses his income for allowances for his school-age children and for household expenses.

Urbano needs to replant to provide a continuous source of income for the family. He needs financial assistance in order to continue operating his farming business. Urbano has requested a loan of PHP 35,000 to buy rice seeds and fertilizers and herbicides for plant care. He hopes to continue operating his farm for the rest of his life.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, and herbicides.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia has applied for a loan from Kiva partner Asasah for her embroidery business. She is an expert in decorative embroidery and makes beautiful clothes for her clients. Razia is motivated to create interesting and beautiful designs on clothes to attract more clients to her business. 

Razia is the mother of two sons and two daughters. All of them are enrolled in a local school and getting their education. She is very experienced in her work and has been operating her business successfully for many years. The income from her business has proven very beneficial in improving her family's life. She can now can support her husband financially.

With the loan, Razia will buy beads, colored thread, and other materials in larger quantities for making even better-looking embroidered clothes. She is confident that a loan will help her to generate more profits from her business.

loans.use: to buy beads and thread for her embroidery business.

loans.name: Medard

texts.en:
Medard is 40 years old and married with five children between the ages of 7 and 18. He owns a business selling various goods such as toilet paper, soap, and sugar. He has 8 years' experience in this business, and he works from 6:00 am until 8:30 pm six days a week. 

Medard has requested a Kiva loan via Vision Finance Company in order to purchase more products to sell. With any profits, he will be able to save for his future, and he will reinvest in his business and renovate his house.

loans.use: to purchase various goods to sell.

loans.name: Kerich

texts.en:
Age 28, Kerich is a farmer in Litein, which is in the South Rift region of Kenya. Kerich is married and has one child, age 2.He has been farming for 12 solid years and currently produces tea, beans, maize and milk, which he sells to the local market in his home area.

Kerich has made a loan request of 35,000 KES from Kiva partner Juhudi Kilimo to purchase pesticides for his farm produce as well as to expand his tea plantation by planting more trees. He says this will boost his farming income and improve his family's living standards.

Kerich says finding capital is his main business challenge. He is glad Juhudi Kilimo is financing farming loans.

loans.use: to buy pesticides for his farm produce as well as to expand his tea plantation by planting more trees.

loans.name: Khaka Group

texts.en:
David is the facilitator of the Khaka group. David and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to David and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

David takes care of three children at home. He joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seed and One Acre Fund's best prices. In the recent 2011 season, David had an excellent maize yield harvesting 18 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, David was only able to harvest four bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from his maize sales, David will build a new house for his family and invest in livestock rearing and business as savings for future use.

In 2012, the members of Khaka group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows David with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Lydia

texts.en:
Lydia is a 60-year-old married woman with six children who are all working. Her husband, Alex, is a businessman who contributes to providing for the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Lydia has operated a clothes-selling business for the past four years; her potential clients are the local area villagers. She faces a major challenge of customers not paying their debts on time. She dreams of establishing a retail shop in the future.

With the 50,000 KES, she wants to purchase more clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to acquire financial help to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more clothes for resale.

loans.name: Bernadette's Group

texts.fr: Le groupe MAHUDJRO est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans le même quartier. C'est la deuxième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Bernadette est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Bernadette est âgée de 41 ans et vit au Bénin. Bernadette  est mariée à un certain Bernard. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Bernadette vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Afin de contribuer aux diverses charges de la famille, Bernadette vend depuis six ans des conserves, du maïs et de la farine de cossette d'igname dans un marché du Bénin. Bernadette s’approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Bernadette sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe MAHUDJRO, un deuxième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Le premier prêt a été bien remboursé.
texts.en:
The Mahudjro group is composed of three persons who live in the same neighborhood. It is the second time that this group is seeking financial support from ALIDé in order to increase the level of their activity. The representative of the group, named Bernadette, is the one with the hand raised on the photo.

Bernadette is 41 years old and lives in Benin. She is married to Bernard. They have two children who are their dependents and all are in school. Bernadette lives together with her husband and children. The couple provides together for all the family’s expenses. To contribute to the various expenses of the family, Bernadette has been selling canned goods, corn and flour made from precooked yam pieces, for six years in a market in Benin. She gets her supplies in a market in Benin.

In the pursuit of her customers’ satisfaction and to increase her turnover and her income, Bernadette is requesting, together with the other members of the Mahudjro group, a second loan from ALIDé. The first loan was fully repaid.

loans.use: to purchase canned goods, and flour made from precooked yam pieces.

loans.name: Esterlita

texts.en:
Esterlita is 54 years old and lives in Galingon, Tampilisan, Zamboanga del Norte. She is married and has five children.

To earn a living, Esterlita has a business selling snacks. She earns about 3000 PHP each month doing this type of work. Esterlita has requested a loan of 10,000 PHP to purchase raw ingredients for her snack-vending business.

Esterlita has been a member of PMPC for two years. In the future, Esterlita would like to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase raw ingredients for her snack-vending business.

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr:
Akou est une femme âgée de 41 ans. Elle est divorcée. Elle a deux enfants.  
Akou travaille comme revendeuse depuis 1996. Elle vend des couches et habits pour bébé pour tous clients au grand marché de Lomé. Elle achète les produits à Lomé. Elle travaille seule.
