Akou a requis son troisième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des couches et des habits pour enfants. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Akou voudrait ouvrir une boutique. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit de prendre soin de sa famille.
texts.en:
Akou is a 41-year-old woman.  She is divorced and has two children.  Akou has been working as a reseller since 1996.  She sells diapers and baby clothes to various customers at the Grand Market in Lomé.  She buys her products in Lomé and works alone.  

Akou requested her third loan from WAGES in order to buy diapers and clothes for children.  She would like to reinvest in her business.  

In the coming years, Akou would like to open a shop.  She says that with the profits she plans to take care of her family.

loans.use: To buy diapers and clothes for children

loans.name: Wilfredo

texts.en:
One of Wilfredo's goals is to improve his farmland and increase his yields to earn a larger income. He is 54 years old and married with six children. Three of his children settled for early marriage, two are college students, and the youngest is in elementary school. Wilfredo did not finish his studies because he didn't have enough money for his education, so he is doing his best to earn a living.

Wilfredo has been involved in agriculture for almost 30 years. He devotes his time to maintaining his rice fields to increase his income. He is thankful that his wife is supportive in improving their lifestyle. She raises hogs and helps Wilfredo with his farming activities. 

Wilfredo would like to purchase certified seeds, fertilizer, and insecticides, but he cannot afford them because of the high cost of basic commodities. In addition, he lacks sufficient income to pay for the labor costs of sowing, transplanting, and tilling the rice farm. He is therefore asking for a loan of PHP 20,000. With this loan, he hopes to improve their financial status and standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizer, and insecticides and pay for labor for his rice farm.

loans.name: Antonia

texts.en:
Antonia is 55 years old and married with six children. Some of her children are already professionals; only her youngest child is still in school. She wishes to continue sending her youngest child to school to complete his education. 

Antonia’s husband is a farmer. Sometimes her husband also works a part-time job to meet the family's needs. Antonia and her husband plant rice in their field within their village. The couple both desire a better yield and to earn a higher income.

Antonia and her husband want to improve their farming practices to achieve their goal. Antonia is asking for a loan of PHP 35,000 to buy hybrid rice seeds and fertilizers. She believes that the loan will have a big impact, because planting hybrid seeds and applying the exact amount of fertilizers will result in a better yield and earn them a higher income.

loans.use: to buy hybrid rice seeds and fertilizers.

loans.name: Carlito

texts.en:
Carlito is 46 years old and married with two children. His primary source of income is rice farming. Together with his wife, he plants and harvests rice from his two-hectare field. Last season, he did not have a good harvest due to an unexpected typhoon that affected their area. He felt sad about what happened to his crops, but he was determined to provide for the needs of his family.

Now he hopes to improve his crop to produce an abundant harvest. Carlito is asking for a loan of PHP 35,000 to buy seedlings and fertilizers and to pay for the labor costs of planting. He wants to ensure good growth of his seedlings.

loans.use: to buy seedlings and fertilizers and to pay for labor.

loans.name: Irenea

texts.en:
Irenea is 49 years old and lives in the Philippines. She is married with three children.
Irenea is a farmer and grows rice to earn a living. She has been doing this for six years. She has requested a loan of 20,000 PHP to purchase fertilizers and vegetables for the growth of her rice farm.
Irenea has been a member of Kiva partner PMPC for five years. In the future, she hopes to save for her family's future.

loans.use: to purchase fertilizers and vegetables.

loans.name: Chenjeni B Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Chenjeni B Group in Western Kenya! Esther is the facilitator of the Chenjeni B group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Esther takes care of three children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Esther had a good maize yield harvesting nine bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Esther was only able to harvest one bag of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Esther and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Esther will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Chenjeni B group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jovie

texts.en:
Jovie is 33 years old. She is a farmer, and her husband helps her to improve their poor standard of living. Farming is their primary source of income, which they use to meet the expenses of everyday living. Over the 10 years they have operated their farming business, Jovie and her husband have experienced a lot of struggles due to typhoons. In spite of this, they stand up, hand in hand.

Jovie is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase two bags of seeds and fertilizers and to pay someone to sow the crops. With their strong determination and hard work, she hopes they will earn a higher income in the coming season.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers and pay for labor.

loans.name: Raphael

texts.en: Raphael is taking another Kiva loan of 50,000 KES to boost his retail shop business. With the loan he wants to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and rice. He dreams of expanding his business into a wholesale shop in the future. Raphael is grateful to Yehu and Kiva lenders for providing loans to boost his business and his living standards.

loans.use: to purchase bundles of wheat flour, maize flour, sugar and rice.

loans.name: Bahodur

texts.ru: Баходур трудолюбивый молодой человек. Он женат, имеет троих детей. Жена домохозяйка. Прокормить большую семью нелегко. У него свой бизнес он имеет 90 голов мелкого рогатого скота и несколько крупного рогатого скота. Также у него свой участок земли, на которой он сеет кукурузу и арбузы. Отходы урожая идут на корм скота. Он хочет получить займ в размере 10 000 сомони на приобретение минеральных удобрений для подготовки к весеннему посеву земли и покупки несколько голов мелкого рогатого скота. Он надеется на помощь и благодарен добрым людям. Спасибо
texts.en: Bahodur is a hardworking young man.  He is married and has three children.  His wife is a homemaker.  It is not easy to provide for a big family.  Bahodur has his own business, and he has 90 heads of small livestock and several cattle.  He also has a plot of land, where he sows corn and watermelons.  The waste from the harvest goes toward feeding livestock.  Bahodur wants to obtain a loan in the sum of 10,000 somoni for the purchase of mineral fertilizers to prepare for the spring sowing and for the purchase of several heads of small livestock.  He hopes to get the help and is grateful to kind people.  Thank you.

loans.use: to purchase mineral fertilizers and livestock

loans.name: Akou

texts.fr:
Akou est une femme âgée de 42 ans. Elle est mariée å un menuisier. Elle a trois enfants.  
Akou travaille comme vendeuse depuis 2000. Elle vend des céréales pour tous clients à domicile. Elle achète les produits à Anié. Elle travaille seule. Au moment, elle n’a pas difficulté. 
Akou a requis son deuxième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des céréales. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Akou voudrait agrandir la taille de son activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit  prendre soin de sa famille.
texts.en:
Akou is a 42-year-old woman. She is married to a carpenter and has three children.

Akou has been working as a saleswoman since 2000. She sells grains for all customers at her home and purchases her wares in Anié. She works alone; at the moment, she has no difficulty.

Akou has requested her second WAGES loan in order to purchase grains. She wants to reinvest in her business.

In the next few years, Akou would like to enlarge her business - with the profits, she intends to take care of her family.

loans.use: To purchase grains.

loans.name: Enkhjargal

texts.en:
Mrs. Enkhjargal, 31, has been working as a hairdresser for ten years. She lives with her husband and three children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. 
Everyday, Enkhjargal cuts the hair of many customers and lately her number of customers has been increasing notably. This is good for her business and her earnings. But there is problem because her equipment, work tools and other appliances are old. When she has a high workload, her hair machine is always jammed and damaged. Therefore, Enkhjargal needs to replace them immediately. The loan she is taking will be dedicated to purchasing new hairdressing equipment and appliances to improve her shop.

loans.use: to purchase new hairdressing equipment and appliances.

loans.name: Benkadi Group

texts.fr:
Les quatre membres du groupe  BENKADI sont essentiellement des femmes mariées avec une moyenne d’âge de 31 ans, et en moyenne 4 enfants. Elles vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames à Médine, dans la ville de Sikasso 3ème région administrative du Mali. 
Elles sont à leur neuvième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame   AWA  en première position à partir de la gauche et tenant deux courges fait le commerce de condiments.
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt, 5 paniers de tomate, 3 cartons de cube maggies qu’elle revendra en détail au marché de Médine à Sikasso à une place fixe et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 40 000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne .
Elle ambitionne d’augmenter son chiffre d’affaire pour mieux satisfaire sa clientèle.
texts.en:
The four members of the Benkadi group are mostly married women with an average age of 31, and an average of 4 children. They live mostly in monogamous families in Medine, in the town of Sikasso, third administrative region of Mali.
This is their ninth loan to meet their customers’ needs with the microfinance institution Soro Yiriwaso.

Madame Awa, first from the left and holding two squashes, sells condiments.
With her loan, she intends to purchase five baskets of tomatoes, three boxes of Maggi cube that she will retail at the market of Medine in Sikasso. She sells for cash at a permanent stall and from home to a clientele composed of men and women.

She plans on making an average monthly profit of 40,000 Francs CFA. Part of which is used to pay the loan and its interest and the other part for her savings. She aims to increase her turnover to better meet her customers’ demand.

loans.use: to purchase condiments.

loans.name: Saing

texts.en:
Mrs. Saing, 25, is a farmer and pig-raiser. She lives in Baray district of Kompong Cham province. She has a common-law relationship with her husband who provides a trailer-motorcycle service in and around the community. Together, this couple is able to earn a good income of $15 per day from their businesses. With this income, Saing has saved some money and kept it for using in a future business. 
Saing is a smart and hopeful housewife who always takes care of the family and maintains her business growth. With a loan of $1,200 from HKL, Kiva’s partner, Saing will buy a rice-husking machine that can be used in the family. Furthermore, she will be able to provide a rice-husking service to local villagers in exchange for money, or she can buy rice with outer cover at a low price from local farmers, and then start husking its cover for sale at a profitable price. In the future, Saing hopes to provide her child with great opportunities and the chance to join a university in Phnom Penh.
The picture shows Saing in front of a thatch house, with her son and two nieces.

loans.use: to buy a rice-husking machine.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: to increase his stock of shoes for resale.

loans.name: Siyabubu

texts.ru:
Сыябюбю -56 лет, замужем и имеет пятерых взрослых детей. После распада Советского Союза, Сыябюбю, в поисках средств к существованию для своей семьи,  начала бизнес в животноводстве и полеводстве. Стартовав с суммы в 20,000 сом (KGS), Сыябюбю сумела развить свое хозяйство, приносящее на сегодня около 7,000 сом ежемесячно от продажи молочных продуктов.  Также, семья Сыябюбю возделывает  3,05 га земли с картофелем и фасолью. 
Для дальнейшего увеличения своего бизнеса, Сыябюбю обратилась в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 100,000 сом (KGS) на покупку двух нетелей и баранов.  В будущем планирует увеличивать свое хозяйство за счет возделывания земли, так как в местности,где она проживает, полеводство является одним из основных занятий местного населения.
texts.en:
Siyabubu is 56 years old, she is married and has five grown children. After the collapse of the Soviet Union Siyabubu was searching for the means to support her family and started her business in animal husbandry and field crop cultivation. Starting with the sum of 20,000 KGS Siyabubu was able to grow her business which brings her today around 7,000 KGS monthly from milk products sales. Also Siyabubu's family sows 3.05 hectares of land with potatoes and beans. 

To further increase her business Siyabubu has come to Bai Tushum and Partners for the loan in the amount of 100,000 KGS to buy two heifers and sheep. She plans to grow her business in the future by cultivating the land because in the area where she lives field crop cultivation is one of the main businesses of the local residents.

loans.use: to purchase cattle.

loans.name: Khakosi A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Khakosi A Group in Western Kenya! Mariciana is the facilitator of the Khakosi A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Mariciana takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Mariciana had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Mariciana was only able to harvest three bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Mariciana and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Mariciana will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Khakosi A group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Kamene

texts.en:
Kamene, age 40, has operated a maize-selling business for the past eight months. She offers her maize for sale to local area residents. Her primary challenge is when debtors do not pay off their debts on time. She dreams of expanding her business.

Kamene and her husband have four children who are all working. They own a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Kamena's greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 
 
With the loan of Kshs 10,000, she wants to purchase more stocks of maize. She decided to join Yehu because of their fair terms and conditions.

loans.use: to purchase more stocks of maize to offer for sale

loans.name: Josephine

texts.en:
Having a happy family is Josephine's only desire. She is 39 years old and married with two children. Her children are completing their college educations, but one of them has had to temporarily stop going to school because of a lack of financial resources. Josephine’s husband is an Overseas Filipino Worker in Malaysia, where he works in a factory. Josephine realizes that a family is not really that happy when someone is far away.

Josephine strives to work so that she can help her husband, even in just a simple way. Josephine has managed her rice farming business for almost 20 years. She wants to borrow PHP 35,000 to pay for labor costs to support her farming activities. She will manage her farm business well to increase her income. In the future, Josephine's husband will return home, and they will live together as a happy family.

loans.use: to pay for labor costs for her rice farm.

loans.name: Silverio

texts.en:
Silverio is a responsible, 47-year-old father who lives in Roma Norte Enrile, Cagayan, with his two children. His wife works abroad as a domestic helper. Silverio raises crops in their village, and he has been planting and harvesting rice for almost 10 years. In the absence of his wife, Silverio serves as both father and mother to his children. 

Silverio wants to increase his crop production, but he has insufficient funds. He is asking for a loan of PHP 20,000 to buy fertilizers and insecticides for his farm. Additional revenue from the business would be used to pay for home improvements and the education of his children. Silverio hopes that someday he will earn enough income that his wife will not have to work abroad anymore.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Nickson

texts.en:
Nickson is aged 33  and married with 3 children aged between 7 and 2. The oldest two are already at school. He lives with his family in their home in Litein where he currently carries out dairy and tea farming. His produce is sold to the local market. He also does timber lumbering.

Nickson has requested a loan of 31,200 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase and insure a dairy cow. He is optimistic that his farming business will grow and help him to provide his family with their basic needs. He aims to make farming his full time activity.

He is however concerned at the poor prices for farm products in the market.

loans.use: to purchase and insure a dairy cow.

loans.name: Kankeletigui Group

texts.fr:
Les cinq membres du groupe  KANKELETIGUI  sont des femmes mariées qui ont en moyenne 30 ans, 3 enfants et qui vivent la plupart dans des familles monogames au quartier Babemba un des nouveaux quartiers de la ville de Sikasso. 
Elles sont à leur huitième prêt avec l’institution de microfinance Soro Yiriwaso afin de satisfaire le besoin de leur clientèle. 
Madame  Haby en jaune se tenant au milieu fait le commerce de pomme de terre. Elle s’approvisionne généralement auprès des producteurs de Sikasso. 
Elle compte acheter avec son  prêt environ 300 Kg de pomme de terre qu’elle revendra en détail au marché de Médine à Sikasso et en famille à une clientèle composée d’hommes et de femmes, au comptant et souvent à crédit. 
 Elle  envisage réaliser un bénéfice mensuel moyen de 30 000 FCFA dont une partie est  utilisée  pour payer le prêt et son intérêt et l’autre pour son épargne.
texts.en:
The five members of the KANKELETIGUI group are married women who are on average 30 years old, have three children and live mostly in monogamous families in Babemba, one of the new districts in the city of Sikasso.

This is their eighth loan with the Soro Yiriwaso microfinance institution, seeking to meet the needs of their customers.

Mrs. Haby, who is standing in the middle dressed in yellow, trades in potatoes. She usually lays in supplies from farmers in Sikasso.

She intends to buy about 300 kg of potatoes with her ​​loan. She will then sell them retail at the Medina market in Sikasso and through home delivery, to both men and women customers, often for cash and also on credit.

She plans to make average monthly profits of 30 000 FCFA, part of which will be used to pay off the loan and its interests, and the rest put into savings.

loans.use: Buy potatoes

loans.name: Joy Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Joy Group in Western Kenya! Jesca is the facilitator of the Joy group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Jesca takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Jesca had a good maize yield harvesting 21 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Jesca was only able to harvest 17 bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jesca and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Jesca will educate her children and acquire more land for cultivation.

In 2012, the members of Joy group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

The photograph shows Joy group members with the Field Officer on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Kabini

texts.en:
Kabini is a 62 year old married woman with seven children who are all independent. Her husband Ngwamba is a farmer who contributes to the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Kabini has operated a retail shop for the past ten years; her potential clients are villagers from the local area. She faces a major challenge which is of people who owe her money not paying their debts on time. She dreams of expanding her business to a wholesale shop in the future.

With the KES 15,000 she wants to purchase stocks of sugar, beans, maize flour and soap for her shop. She decided to join Yehu to access funding to improve her standard of living.

loans.use: to purchase stocks of sugar, beans, maize flour and soap for her shop.

loans.name: Kokoé

texts.fr:
Kokoè est une femme âgée de 31 ans. Elle est mariée å un gérant de restaurant. Elle a deux enfants.  
Kokoè travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2005. Elle vend du riz, des boissons et des articles en plastiques pour tous clients à domicile. Elle achète les produits au grand marché de Lomé. Elle travaille seule. 
Kokoè a requis son deuxième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter du riz de l’huile et des boissons. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Kokoè voudrait ouvrir une boutique. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille.
texts.en:
Kokoè is a 31-year old woman. She is married to a restaurant manager. She has two children.
Kokoè has been working as a vendor since 2005. She sells rice, beverages and plastic items out of her home, to all kinds of clients. She buys her goods at the 
big market of Lomé. She works by herself.

Kokoè has requested her second loan from WAGES in order to buy rice, vegetable oil and beverages. She would like to make a new investment in her business. In the years to come, Kokoè would like to open a store. She says that she plans to use her revenues to improve life conditions of her family.

loans.use: to buy 4 jugs of oil, 5 bags of rice and canned beverages

loans.name: Otgonbaatar

texts.en:
Mr. Otgonbaatar, 51, a divorced man whose children live with his former spouse, operates a taxi around the districts of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. A former bus driver with over 30 years of experience, he has been conducting his business since 2009.

In order to provide better service and increase his business volume, he recently replaced his old Russian car with a new Toyota Carina. Otgonbaatar is now requesting this loan to cover the cost of his new car.

loans.use: to cover the cost of his new car for his taxi business.

loans.name: Progressive A Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Progressive A Group in Western Kenya! Susan is the facilitator of the Progressive A group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Susan takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund because One Acre Fund has the best prices and to ensure food for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Susan had an excellent maize yield harvesting 11 bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Susan was only able to harvest five bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Susan and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Susan will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Progressive A group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Webanania Group

texts.en:
Macdonald is the facilitator of the Webanania group. Macdonald and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.
Macdonald takes care of nine children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds. In the recent 2011 season, Macdonald had a very good maize yield harvesting eight bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund,  Macdonald was only able to harvest three bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Macdonald and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Macdonald will educate his children and save for future use.

In 2012, the members of Webanania group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Macdonald is pictured with his group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is a 32-year-old widowed woman. She has three children who go to school. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is school fees for her children. 

Faith has run a business selling maize for the past four years; her potential clients are residents of the local area. She has a major challenge which is transportation. She dreams of setting up a retail shop.

With the KES 10,000 she wants to purchase 28 sacks of maize for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial facilities.

loans.use: to purchase 28 sacks of maize for resale.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy potatoes

loans.name: Abra

texts.fr:
Abra est une femme âgée de 28 ans. Elle a deux enfants.  
Abra travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2009. Elle vend des chaussures et des pagnes pour tous clients au grand marché. Elle achète les produits à Lomé. Elle travaille seule. 
Abra a requis son deuxième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des chaussures et des pagnes. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Abra voudrait ouvrir une boutique. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit d’assurer l’éducation de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Abra is a 28-year-old woman. She has two children.

Abra has been working as a retailer since 2009. She sells shoes and pagnes [colorful cloth used in traditional dress] for all customers at the large market. She purchases her wares in Lomé and works alone.

Abra has requested her second WAGES loan in order to purchase shoes and pagnes. She wants to reinvest in her business.

In the next few years, Abra would like to open a boutique. With the profits, she intends to provide for her children's education.

loans.use: To purchase pagnes [colorful cloth used in traditional dress] and shoes.

loans.name: Restituto

texts.en:
Restituto owns and manages a 1.5-hectare rice field. He is 36 years old and married with five children. He works hard to earn a living. He has managed his rice field for four years, and he earns about PHP 40,000 per season. But this past season, he did not obtain his expected yields due to the disastrous effects of October's typhoon. His profit goes immediately to meet his obligations to traders who charge high rates of interest. He has no choice but to pay these high interest rates, because there are no other traders within their village.

Restituto would like to ask for additional capital amounting to PHP 30,000 to buy farm inputs and gasoline and to pay for labor to transplant and sow rice crops on his farmland. With this loan, he could improve his farming practices, which will give him better yields this coming season. He hopes that he can improve his rice production in order to save some money and provide his family with a better future.

loans.use: to buy farm supplies and gasoline and to pay for labor.

loans.name: Joyce

texts.en:
Joyce is a 37-year-old a married woman with six children between the age of 14 and 2 years old. Five of them are in school. 

She has had a business selling tea in Buluk, South Sudan, for two years. Joyce requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase sugar and milk powder for her tea business. 

She will use the extra income she gets from this loan to pay for the school fees of her children in the future.

loans.use: to purchase sugar and milk powder to make tea for sale.

loans.name: Umoja Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Umoja Group in Western Kenya! Beatrice is the facilitator of the Umoja group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Beatrice takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Beatrice had a very good maize yield harvesting 20 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Beatrice was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Beatrice and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Beatrice will pay loans and ensure food security.

Beatrice is pictured with her group members in the photograph above.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Brenson

texts.en:
Brenson is 25 years old and married with one kid. Brenson's wife is a private employee in an organization in the Philippines. Her salary is used for their daily household expenses.

Brenson is a farmer, planting rice in their village. He has been in the business for almost five years, and he learned about farming from his parents. Brenson's business serves as an extra source of income and savings for the family.

Brenson's wife's salary is not enough to finance both their daily needs and the inputs needed for farming. He is requesting a loan of PHP 35,000 to buy rice seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides. Brenson hopes to have better yields and earn a higher income to save for his family's future emergency needs.

loans.use: to buy rice seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides.

loans.name: Rotich

texts.en:
Rotich is a farmer in the Litein area of the South Rift Valley, Kenya. He has been farming here for 9 years. He is aged 27 and married with one child aged 3. His farm produces tea, milk and vegetables for the local market.

Rotich has requested a loan of 40,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to purchase a motorcycle for his transport business. He says the motorcycle will help him to make deliveries to the market in addition to earning money from providing services to other farmers. He sees his costs going down and his income going up, and being able to give his family a better standard of living.

He mentions poor markets and weather as the greatest challenges to farmers in the area.

loans.use: to buy a motorcycle.

loans.name: Anonymous Group
loans.use: Buy condiments

loans.name: Angaza A Farmers Group

texts.en:
Chenge is the facilitator of the Angaza A Farmers group. Chenge and his group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Chenge takes care of 10 children at home. He joined One Acre Fund to access fertilizer and hybrid seed. In the recent 2011 season, Chenge had an excellent maize yield harvesting 10 bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Chenge was only able to harvest three bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Chenge and his group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from his maize sales, Chenge will educate his children.

In 2012, the members of Angaza A Farmers group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Chenge is pictured with his group members. The field officer is on the far left.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Soulemana

texts.fr:
Soulemana est un homme âgé de 29 ans. Il est célibataire. Il a un enfant
Soulemana travaille comme vendeur depuis 2006. Il vend des produits vétérinaires pour tous clients à domicile. Il achète les produits à Agbalepédo, Agoè et Wuiti. Il travaille seul. 
Soulemana a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des produits vétérinaires. Il veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
 Il dit qu’avec les profits, il prévoit de se marier.
texts.en:
Soulemana is a 29-year-old man. He is unmarried and has one child.
Soulemana has worked as a retailer since 2006. He sells veterinary products for all types of customers at his home. He buys his products at Agbalepédo, Agoè, and Wuiti. He works by himself.
Soulemana has requested his first loan from WAGES in order to buy veterinary products. He wants to reinvest in his business.
He says that with the profits, he intends to get married.

loans.use: To buy veterinary products.

loans.name: Lucie

texts.fr: Lucie est âgée de 42 ans et est mariée à un conducteur du nom de Nicodem. Le couple a quatre enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. Lucie vit ensemble avec ses enfants et son mari. Pour assurer ses différentes charges et contribuer aux besoins de sa famille, Lucie mène comme activité la vente de tissus par le système de distribution. De façon secondaire, Lucie vend des arachides grillés. Lucie exerce cette activité depuis deux ans. Lucie s'approvisionne dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour améliorer son niveau de vie, Lucie sollicite pour une quatrième fois, un crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les trois premiers crédits ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
Lucy is 42 years old and is married to a driver named Nicodemus. The couple has four children, all attending school and under their care. Lucie lives together with her children and her husband.

To manage her various responsibilities and contribute towards family expenses, Lucy's business activity has been to sell fabrics through the distribution system. Secondarily, Lucy also sells roasted peanuts.

Lucie has been in business for the past two years. She resupplies from a market in Benin.

Seeking to satisfy her customers and improve her standard of living, Lucy is requesting a fourth credit loan from ALIDé. The first three loans have been repaid in full.

loans.use: Buy fabrics and bags of peanuts.

loans.name: Huruma C Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Huruma C Group in Western Kenya! Dorcus is the facilitator of the Huruma C group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Dorcus takes care of two children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and educate her children. In the recent 2011 season, Dorcus had an excellent maize yield harvesting 24 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Dorcus was only able to harvest five bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Dorcus and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Dorcus will educate her children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Huruma C group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

In the picture above, Dorcus is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs such as seeds and fertilizer at low prices for the 2012 planting season

loans.name: Riolita

texts.en:
At the age of 35, Riolita has four children, all of whom are in elementary school. She needs to work hard because she wishes to give them the opportunity to attend high school and college. She wants them to have a better future, and education is the only treasure she can give them.

Riolita runs a rice farming business. She and her husband manage their business, and they work together to achieve better results. Riolita always prays that she will get better yields from her crops. If she can maintain her farming business, she believes that it will be enough to continue sending her children to school. 

Riolita is requesting a loan of PHP 30,000 to purchase seeds and fertilizers for her rice farming business. She looks forward to the success of her business.

loans.use: to purchase seeds and fertilizers for rice farming.

loans.name: Baljinyam

texts.en:
Mr. Baljinnyam is 31. He is a driver of minivan which he uses for transportation services in the different districts of Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. He has been doing this business since 2007. 

Before starting this business, he used to drive a taxi. He changed his work as it gave him less income. He lives with his family in a ger, a Mongolian traditional nomadic tent which is located in the ger district. 

Lately his business income has dropped, mainly because his minivan has damage to its cabin and its parts. The satisfaction of his customers is at the core of his business, and it depends on the quality of his service. Therefore he has decided to make some changes to the cabin of his minivan and to its spare parts.

According his calculations, his earnings and the frequency of his service will increase after the renovation. 

The loan he is taking will be dedicated to purchasing new spare parts and to renovating the cabin of his minivan to improve his service.

loans.use: to have a better transportation service by purchasing spare parts and renovating the cabin of his minivan.

loans.name: Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia

texts.fr: Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia est âgée de 34 ans et est mariée à un informaticien du nom de Thierry. Le couple a deux enfants, tous scolarisés et à leur charge. En plus de leurs enfants, le couple a un autre enfant à charge. Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants et assure ensemble avec son mari les diverses charges de la famille. Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia n'a pas fréquenté l'école. Il y a environs cinq ans que Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia mène comme activité la vente de produits de beauté et des tissus dans un marché du Bénin. Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia s'approvisionne au Bénin. C'est la troisième fois que Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia sollicite un appui financier de ALIDé, afin de renforcer son activité et de mieux répondre aux exigences de sa clientèle.
texts.en:
Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia is 34 years old and is married to a computer specialist named Thierry. They have two children both in school and under their care. In addition to their own children, the couple has another dependent child.

Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia lives with her husband and children and shares with him responsibility for the various household expenses.

Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia has not attended school. For the past five years her business activity has been to sell cosmetics and fabrics in one of Benin's markets. She replenishes her stock in Benin.

This is the third time Eyi Ablanvi Hélénia has sought financial support from ALIDé, to strengthen her business and better meet customer requirements.

loans.use: Buy beauty products and fabrics.

loans.name: Elizabeth

texts.en:
Elizabeth is a married woman with five children. Two of them are enrolled in school while the others have completed school. Her husband is a farmer who contributes to the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Elizabeth has operated a retail shop for the past two years; her potential clients are the residents of the local area. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the KES 20,000 she wants to purchase two sacks of maize flour and wheat flour for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial facilities.

loans.use: to purchase two sacks of maize flour and wheat flour for resale.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is 30 year old a married woman with four children between the age of 19 and 8. All of them are in school.  She has had a business selling charcoal in Buluk south Sudan for a year.

Mary requested this loan through Brac South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use the extra income that she will generate to build a concrete house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Mzabibu Group

texts.en:
Greetings from Mzabibu Group in Western Kenya! Lonah is the facilitator of the Mzabibu group. This group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Lonah takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Lonah had an excellent maize yield harvesting nine bags on 1/2 acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Lonah was only able to harvest four bags of maize on 1/2 acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Lonah and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Lonah will educate her children, ensure food security and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Mzabibu group will each plant between ½ and 1 acre of maize.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Monica

texts.en:
Monica is a mother of four children, ages 23, 19, 17 and 9, with the last two children still in school. She has been in the farming business for 10 years and currently produces beans, potatoes, maize and milk, which she sells to the local market.

Monica has made a loan request for 35,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo. She would like to use 32,000 KES to purchase a water tank and 3,000 KES for irrigation pipes. She says this will help her production during dry spells and improve her income, which will be helpful in educating her two youngest children.

Monica says her main business challenge is inadequate rainfall for farming. She says she has a long-term plan of acquiring more farm land. She adds that Juhudi Kilimo loans are helpful since they come with grace periods.

loans.use: to purchase a water tank and irrigation pipes.

loans.name: Kache

texts.en:
Kache is a married woman with five children, two of whom are enrolled in school while the others are grownups. Her husband is a businessman who contributes to providing for the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Kache has operated a livestock-selling business (goats and cattle) for the past two years; her potential clients are the local area residents. She faces a major challenge of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the 40,000 KES, she wants to purchase more goats and cattle for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access financial facilities to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more goats and cattle for resale.

loans.name: Grace

texts.en:
Grace is 20 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. She is married and has one child. For the past two years, Grace has been working hard to manage her hairdressing salon for local women. 

To help expand her business, Grace has requested a loan of 200,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids and will help Grace to generate greater profits and expand her business. Grace hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own. 

Grace is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to providing micro-finance loans, the program provides both a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Grace's future prospects by helping her to improve her business.

loans.use: to purchase the equipment needed to do special braids.

loans.name: Komil

texts.ru: Комил женат и у них 5 детей. Более 5 лет он предоставляет услуги такси в своем городе. Он очень трудолюбивый человек и всегда старается работать  ради обеспечения своих детей. Его автомобиль находится в хорошем состоянии.  Он имеет много постоянных клиентов, так как большинство жителей поселка работают в городе. Чтобы купить запчасти и отремонтировать свою автомашину он запрашивает займ. Он надеется на вашу помощь и заранее благодарен вам за поддержку и милосердие.
texts.en: Komil is married and has five children.  He has been providing a taxi service in his town for over five years.  Komil is a very hardworking person, who always tried to work hard in order to provide for his children.  His car is in a good condition.  He has many regular clients because many of the village residents work in the city.  Komil is requesting this loan to buy spare parts and make repairs to his car.  He hopes to get your help and thanks you in advance for the support and mercy.

loans.use: to purchase spare parts and make repairs to his car

loans.name: Monika

texts.en:
Monika is a 48-year-old married woman with six children, from 10 to 36 years old. Five of her children are in school. For the past nine years, she has been selling clothes in bulk in South Sudan.

Monika requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase clothes. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase clothes to sell.

loans.name: Faith

texts.en:
Faith is 21 years old and lives in the town of Kyengera in the Kampala North region of Uganda. For the past two years, Faith has been working hard to manage her retail shop, which sells sugar and soap. 

To help expand her business, Faith has requested a loan of 500,000 Ugandan Shillings from BRAC Uganda. The loan will be used to purchase supplies for resale and will help Faith to generate greater profits and buy new clothes for herself. Faith hopes that in the future she will be able to build a house of her own. 

Faith is a member of BRAC's Empowerment and Livelihood for Adolescents (ELA) program. In addition to offering micro-finance loans, the program provides a safe place for young Ugandan women to take part in group activities and a forum for life-skills training. The ELA program has increased Faith's future prospects by helping her improve her earnings.

loans.use: to purchase supplies for resale.

loans.name: Lango

texts.en:
Lango is 43 years old, lives in an airport community, and was educated to the ninth grade. She has five children between 16 to 27 years old; three are in college and working and living on their own, while the two younger ones are in school and live at home. Lango's husband is a businessman.

For the past 14 years, Lango has been selling cold drinks like soda, and soft drinks, to sustain her and her family. She is requesting a loan to purchase soda and soft drinks for her business. Her plans are to build a house and send her younger children to college.

loans.use: to purchase soda and soft drinks for her business.

loans.name: Chrisps Group

texts.en:
Jecinta is the facilitator of the Chrisps group. Jecinta and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Jecinta takes care of six children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to obtain One Acre Fund’s best prices and to increase her maize production. In the recent 2011 season, Jecinta had a good maize yield harvesting 12 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jecinta was only able to harvest eight bags of maize on one acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jecinta and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from maize sales, Jecinta will educate her children and invest in livestock rearing.

In 2012, the members of Chrisps group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

In the photograph above, Jecinta is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Omar

texts.ru:
Омар 50-летний фермер, живущий в с .Учкун. Имеет троих детей, жена работает учителем в местной школе.  С 1981 года семья Омара успешно занимается разведением скота и полеводством. Начав с приобретения одной коровы, Омар смог  увеличить поголовье до четырех коров и пяти баранов, а также у него имеются 2,5 тонны кукурузы для последующей продажи. Доходы от такой бизнес - деятельности  позволили Омару приобрести машину для своей семьи.  
 Для дальнейшего увеличения поголовья скота, Омар обратился в компанию «Бай – Тушум и Партнеры» за кредитом в сумме 50,000 сом (KGS) для покупки дойной коровы. Планируемую прибыль Омар намерен использовать для постройки нового сарая в целях обеспечения хороших условий для содержания скота.
texts.en: Omar is 50 year-old farmer, who lives in the Uchkun village.  He has three children, and his wife works as a teacher at the local school.  Since 1981, Omar's family has been successfully involved in breeding livestock and farming.  Having started with a purchase of one cow, Omar was able to grow the livestock headcount to four cows and five sheep.  He also has 2.5 tons of corn for the next sale.  Profits from this business allowed Omar to buy a car for his family.  In order to further increase livestock headcount, Omar requested a loan in the sum of 50,000 som (KGS) from the "Bai-Tushum and Partners" company to purchase a dairy cow.  He intends to use the planned profit to build a new barn in order to provide good conditions for keeping livestock.

loans.use: to purchase a dairy cow

loans.name: Sinoko B Group

texts.en:
Bridgid is the facilitator of the Sinoko B group. Bridgid and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Bridgid and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

She joined One Acre Fund to access One Acre's best prices and to ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Bridgid had an excellent maize yield harvesting 18 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Ace Fund, Bridgid was only able to harvest seven bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from her maize sales, Bridgid will educate her children and save for future use.

In 2012, the members of Sinoko B group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Bridgid pictured together with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Zinabou

texts.fr:
Zinabou est une femme âgée de 42 ans. Elle est veuve. Elle a trois enfants.  
Zinabou travaille comme revendeuse depuis 2000. Elle  vend des céréales pour tous clients dans une boutique. Elle achète les produits à l’intérieur du pays. Elle travaille seule. Au moment, sa difficulté est la mévente.
Zinabou a requis son premier crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des céréales. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Zinabou voudrait augmenter la taille de l’activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit de financer les études de ses enfants.
texts.en:
Zinabou is a 42-year-old woman. She is a widow and has three children.
Zinabou has worked as a retailer since 2000. She sells cereals at a store to all types of customers. She buys her products in the interior of the country. She works alone. Currently, her biggest difficulty is a slump in sales.
Zinabou has requested her first loan from WAGES in order to buy cereals. She wants to reinvest in her business.
In the coming years, Zinabou would like to increase the size of her business. She says that with the profits, she intends to finance her children's education.

loans.use: To buy cereals.

loans.name: Charito

texts.en:
Charito is 51 years old and engaged in wax manufacturing. She has been in this business for 20 years. Through her livelihood, her family can pass the day with full stomachs. Because of her hardworking character, they never miss a single meal.

With her 20 years of experience, Charito can say that her product leads the competition. Because of its high quality, her floor wax captivates more customers. To meet her target market demand, she is asking for a loan of PHP 10,000 to purchase additional raw materials to make floor wax. She hopes that her business will grow progressively in order to meet the needs of her family and lift them from poverty.

loans.use: to purchase additional raw materials to make floor wax.

loans.name: Emmanuel

texts.en:
Emmanuel, age 49, strives to support himself and his parents. He has a small eatery business on the CSU campus, so most of his customers are students from the school compound. Due to his delicious recipes and friendly character, he has garnered a lot of customers. He serves a large group of students every day. 

He wishes to add new dishes to the menu as well as to ensure that he has food in large enough quantities to meet customer demand. This is why he has decided to request a loan in the amount of P20,000 in order to purchase vegetables, meat, and additional ingredients and materials for his eatery, including spoons, forks, and glasses.
 
He is confident that this loan amount will allow him to expand his business and to help lift his parents from poverty. He also intends to help others by offering any surplus food from his business to the needy.

loans.use: to purchase vegetables, meat, and additional ingredients and materials for his eatery, including spoons, forks, and glasses

loans.name: Jenty

texts.en:
Jenty is 38-year-old married woman with four children between the ages of 3 and 19 years old. All of them are in school. She has had a business selling bread in Buluk, South Sudan, for five years.

Jenty requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase bread for resale. She will use her extra income from this loan to pay the school fees of her children.

loans.use: to purchase bread for resale.

loans.name: Reuy

texts.en:
Reuy, 55, is widowed and has five children. One of them is a dependent, while the other four are married, working as hairdresser and as a construction worker. Reuy is a farmer in a rural area of Moung Russey District. She also raises pigs and runs a small store selling face powder to generate additional income to feed her family. She has been in this business for 15 years to make a living. 

Reuy has been with VisionFund since 2007, and she completely repaid the loan with VisionFund. The loans from VisionFund help her to have regular income and sufficiently feed her children. Now she is requesting for a fourth loan. She will use this loan to buy more piglets for her business. She hopes to earn more income from this business and can build on some savings for future needs.

loans.use: to buy piglets for her pig raising business.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to buy seeds and fertilizers and to pay for the labor of a farm worker

loans.name: Chizi

texts.en:
Chizi is a married woman with four children who are all adults. Her husband is a farmer who contributes to providing for the family's basic needs. She owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for her family. 

Chizi has operated a clothes selling business for the past 10 years; her potential clients are the local area residents. She faces a major challenge of seasonality. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 30,000, she wants to purchase more stock of clothes for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access fund to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of clothes for resale.

loans.name: Lorna

texts.en:
Lorna is a small farmer in her local community. She is a very industrious worker who has been engaged in this business with her husband for 10 years. This is their main source of income and they support their family through the proceeds from their farm.
 
Due to lack of finances, Lorna is asking for a loan amount P15,000 to buy inputs needed on the farm, including two bags of seeds, a liter of insecticides, and fertilizers, and to pay for the labor of an additional worker who will sow and plow the farm.  

Through their sacrifices, patience, and hard work, Lorna is confident that they will achieve progress and success.

loans.use: to buy inputs needed on the farm, including two bags of seeds, a liter of insecticides, and fertilizers, and to pay for the labor of an additional farm worker

loans.name: Emerson

texts.en:
Emerson is a 21 year old farmer.  Because of financial problems he did not finish his college studies.  He helps his parents manage their small farm.  In the future, he wants to continue his studies. 

Emerson is asking for a loan of P10,000 to buy fertilizers, seeds and to pay for laborers.  

With his unending patience and industriousness, he will hopes to continue his studies soon.  Hopefully, he will harvest a more profitable crops next season.

loans.use: to buy fertilizers, seeds and to pay for laborers.

loans.name: Akoua

texts.fr:
Akoua est une femme âgée de 62 ans. Elle est veuve et a six enfants.  
Akoua travaille comme revendeuse depuis 1985. Elle vend des céréales et des tubercules pour tous clients à domicile. Elle achète les produits à Anié et Tabligbo. Elle travaille seule. Au moment, sa difficulté principale est  trouver du capital pour renforcer son activité. 
Akoua a requis son deuxième crédit de WAGES afin d’acheter des céréales et des tubercules d’ignames. Elle veut réinvestir dans l’activité. 
Dans les prochaines années, Akoua voudrait augmenter la taille de l’activité. Elle dit qu’avec les profits, elle prévoit  prendre soin de sa famille.
texts.en:
Akoua is a 62-year-old woman. She is a widow and has six children.
Akoua has worked as a retailer since 1985. She cells cereals and tubers at her home to all types of customers. She buys her products in Anié and Tabligbo. She works by herself. At the moment, her main difficulty is finding capital to strengthen her business.
Akoua has requested her second loan from WAGES in order to buy cereals and yam tubers. She wants to reinvest in her business.
In the coming years, Akoua would like to increase the size of her business. She says that with the profits, she intends to take care of her family.

loans.use: To buy cereals and yams.

loans.name: Namik

texts.en:
Namik is 42 years old and married. He owns and operates a milk production business and sells at a bazaar.
   
He has been involved in this business for 20 years. The income from the sale of milk helps him to improve his family's livelihood. His plans for the future are to increase the production of milk and his sales. With the loan he is requesting, he will purchase more cows. He hopes you will support him in his business goals.

loans.use: to purchase cattle

loans.name: Benelin

texts.en:
Benelin is 46 years old and blessed with two children who are students.  To provide for their needs, Benelin and her husband are farmers.  

It is difficult to engage in this kind of business because it requires hard work and patience.

Benelin acquired these characteristics but feels financial constrained.  She is asking for a loan of P15,000 to buy inputs needed in their business.  She will buy seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and pay to hired worker to help on their farm land. 

She will utilize her loan to make her business progress.

loans.use: to buy seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and pay to hired worker to help on their farm land.

loans.name: Njete Shg Group

texts.en:
Jane is the facilitator of the Njete SHG group. Jane and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

Jane takes care of eight children at home. She joined One Acre Fund to access One Acre Fund’s best prices and to ensure food security for her family and later educate them. In the recent 2011 season, Jane had a very good maize yield harvesting 10 bags on ½ acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Jane was only able to harvest 2½ bags of maize on ½ acre of land.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Jane and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

With income from her maize sales, Jane will educate her children and save for the future.

In 2012, the members of Njete SHG group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land and the person standing on the far left is the field officer.


In the photograph above, Jane is pictured with her group members.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Jackie

texts.en:
Jackie is a 24 years old college graduate who helps his parents operate their small farm.  He is actively looking for a better paying job.

Jackie is asking for a loan of P14,000 to purchase seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and farm inputs.  He wants to provide for the needs of their farm to endow it with a lot of profit.

loans.use: to purchase seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and farm inputs.

loans.name: Bashiraan's Group

texts.en:
Bashiraan is 46 years old, married and has children.  Her eldest son operates a cosmetics selling business and earns a good profit.  He also has some good clients. 

Her husband sells balloons of different shapes which attracts many children towards him.  He has good sales everyday.  

Bashiraan also supports her husband financially by making Pranday (ornament used to tie up hairs and it is very popular among women) that sells for a very good price. 

Besides her business, she also manages her household very well. 

She has applied for a loan from KIVA partner Asasah for her eldest son, for his cosmetic selling business.  With the loan, he will buy cosmetics such as eye shadow, mascara, nail polish, etc. in bulk. 

He has operated his business for many years and Bashiraan is hopeful that an investment will help him make his business more profitable.

loans.use: to buy cosmetics such as eye shadow, mascara, nail polish, etc. in bulk.

loans.name: Sharon

texts.en:
Sharon is a 31 years old farmer. With the help of her husband, they operate their business smoothly.  She wants to earn more profit for the security of her three children. Therefore, the couple is working hard to provide for their needs as well as to save for emergency purposes.

Sharon is asking for a loan of P10,000 to buy input needed of their farm such as seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and gasoline used for a tractor to plow the land.  Through these inputs, she hopes to improve their business.  Sharon wants to escape their poor lifestyle for something better.

loans.use: to buy input needed of their farm such as seeds, fertilizers, insecticides and gasoline used for a tractor to plow the land.

loans.name: Redante

texts.en:
Redante is 46 years old, married and blessed with four children.  He is a farmer and this enables him to provide for the needs of his family. 

As he stated, “It is role of a father to raise a family.”  For this reason, he is asking for a loan of P13,000 to purchase needed inputs such as seeds, fertilizers and insecticides.

Through these inputs, he would be able to yield a higher profit during the harvesting season.  By then, he could save for the future of his children.

loans.use: to purchase needed inputs such as seeds, fertilizers and insecticides.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase paracetimol, ibuprofen, and cough syrup for her business

loans.name: Margret

texts.en:
Margret is 35 year old  and married with five children between the ages of 16-3 years old. All of her children are in the school. She has had a business selling food at a stall in Buluk, South Sudan for six years.

Margret requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase tomatoes and onions for her food stall. she will use her extra income from this loan to build a house.

loans.use: to purchase tomatoes and onions for resale.

loans.name: Juanito

texts.en:
Juanito is a 31 years old farmer.  He is married and blessed with four children.  This business is their primary source of income, hence he cares a lot to generate a high crop yield.

For this reason, he is asking a loan of P10,000 to buy insecticides, seeds and fertilizers inputs needed in his farm.  Hopefully, his farming efforts will provide a greater profit.  Juanito hopes to save for the future of his family.

loans.use: to buy insecticides, seeds and fertilizers inputs needed in his farm.

loans.name: Dexterjay

texts.en:
Dexterjayr is a 18 years old farmer.  He just finished high school and could not enter college due to the financial problems of his parents. 

For this reason, he helps his father operate their farm.  Dexterjay is asking for a loan of P13,000 to buy inputs needed in their farm such as seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides. 

He is hoping that, the loan and his efforts will generate more profits in the next harvesting season.  He hopes to use some of the funds for his studies and to benefit his siblings.  He dreams to become a police officer.  He strives with a content smile in his face.

loans.use: to buy inputs needed in their farm such as seeds, fertilizers, and insecticides.

loans.name: Riziki

texts.en:
Riziki is a single woman who owns a house with neither electricity nor piped water. Her greatest monthly expense is food for herself. 

Riziki has operated a charcoal selling business for the past seven years; her potential clients are the local are residents. She faces a major challenge of transportation. She dreams of expanding her business.

With the Kshs 20,000, she wants to purchase more stock of charcoal for resale. She decided to join Yehu to access funds to expand her business.

loans.use: to purchase more stock of charcoal for resale.

loans.name: Julius

texts.en:
Julius, 34, is a resident and a farmer in the Nkubu area of Central Kenya, where he carries out farming as well as a transport business. He is married with two children, ages 9 and 7. He has been in active farming for 10 years and currently sells beans, maize and wheat produced locally.

Julius has requested for a loan of 40,000 KES from Juhudi Kilimo to buy dairy goats. He says these goats will be able to provide him with milk during dry seasons. He says the loan will help him improve his farming by buying dairy cows in the future and provide income to educate his children.

He sees rampant drought as the main challenge to farmers.

loans.use: to buy dairy goats.

loans.name: La Esperanza Group

texts.es:
El Comité "La Esperanza" tiene 10 integrantes, todas ellas mujeres muy trabajadoras y luchadoras. Ellas han demostrado unión y solidaridad las unas con las otras. Todas son de la ciudad de Villa Ygatimi, son vecinas y amigas de esa ciudad.
Una de ellas es la señora Otilia, quien se dedica a la cría y venta de animales de corral, como ser cerdos y gallinas. Por medio de su trabajo y su esfuerzo ha logrado mantener a su familia y cuidar del hogar, por lo que no se cansa de luchar. Comenta que tiene buena venta de sus animales, por lo que le gustaría seguir trabajando en el.
Por ello solicita la ayuda de la fundación y de kiva para la compra de cerdos pequeños, para la cría y posterior venta. Agradece a la fundación y a kiva también por esta oportunidad.
texts.en:
The "La Esperanza" [Hope] committee has ten members, all very hard-working, industrious women. They have shown their union and solidarity with each other. All of them are from the city of Villa Ygatimi; they are neighbors and friends from that city.

One of them is Otilia, who earns a living raising and selling farm animals, such as pigs and chickens. Through her work and efforts, she has been able to support her family and take care of her home; because of this, she never gets tired of working to get ahead. She says that sales of her animals are good, so she would like to continue this work.

Because of this, she is asking for the help of the foundation and Kiva to purchase young pigs to raise and then sell. She thanks the foundation and also Kiva for this opportunity.

loans.use: purchase young pigs to raise and then sell.

loans.name: Anouolouwa Group

texts.fr: Le groupe ANOUOLOUWA est composé de trois personnes qui résident dans la même zone. C'est la quatrième fois que ce groupe sollicite l'aide financier de ALIDé, afin d'élever le niveau de son activité. La représentante  du groupe, du nom de Rafiath est celle qui a la main levée sur la photo. Rafiath est âgée de 34 ans. Rafiath a arrêté l'école au niveau secondaire. Rafiath est mariée à un revendeur du nom de Bernard. Le couple a deux enfants tous scolarisés et à leur charge. En plus des deux enfants, le couple a un autre enfant à leur charge.  Rafiath vit ensemble avec son mari et ses enfants. Le couple assure ensemble les charges de la famille. Afin de contribuer aux diverses charges de la famille, Rafiath vend depuis quatre ans, divers produits (lait, savons, sucre, etc.) et des liqueurs dans sa région. Rafiath achète ses produits dans un marché du Bénin. Dans la quête de la satisfaction de sa clientèle et pour accroître son chiffre d’affaires et son revenu, Rafiath sollicite ensemble avec les autres membres du groupe ANOUOLOUWA, un quatrième crédit auprès de ALIDé. Les trois premiers crédits ont été bien remboursés.
texts.en:
ANOUOLOUWA Group is made up of three persons who live in the same area. They are seeking their fourth loan from Kiva's partner, ALIDé, in order to bolster their businesses.

The group's representative, named Rafiath, is the one raising her hand in the photograph. She dropped out of middle school. She's 34 years old and married to a reseller named Bernard.

The couple has two school-attending children. In addition, they have another kid to support. The couple takes care of the family expenses together.

To help with the family expenses, Rafiath has been selling various products (milk, soaps, sugar, etc) and liquors in her region for four years. She gets her supplies in a market in Benin.

Eager to satisfy her clientele and increase her revenue, Rafiath, together with the other members of the group, is seeking her fourth loan from ALIDé. The first three loans were repaid without problems.

loans.use: to buy various products (boxes of milk, soaps, and sugar)

loans.name: Kabuchai Group

texts.en:
Christine is the facilitator of the Kabuchai B group. Christine and her group joined One Acre Fund in the year 2011 and will re-enroll in the 2012 program.

With this loan, One Acre Fund will purchase fertilizer, seeds, and other important inputs to distribute to Christine and her group during Kenya’s next planting season in February 2012. The distribution of farming inputs is part of One Acre Fund’s integrated agriculture package, which includes training, reliable input supply (such as fertilizer and seeds), credit and insurance.

She joined One Acre Fund in order to access fertilizer and hybrid seeds and ensure food security for her family. In the recent 2011 season, Christine had an excellent maize yield harvesting 20 bags on one acre of land. Before joining One Acre Fund, Christine was only able to harvest six bags of maize on one acre of land.

With income from her maize sales, Christine will invest in livestock rearing and save for the future to repay her loans.

In 2012, the members of Kabuchai B group will each plant maize plots between ½ and 1 acre of land.

The photograph shows Christine pictured with her group members. Standing on the far left is the field officer.

loans.use: To source farming inputs, such as seeds and fertilizer, at low prices for the 2012 planting season.

loans.name: Orn

texts.en: Orn is a 32-year-old married woman and the mother of two children who are of the age for attending school. She is a local farmer, cultivating crops such as rice, potatoes and beans. From this business, she is able to earn in the neighborhood of $3.60 per day and tries hard to support her family. Orn would like to borrow some funds from HKL and Kiva to add to her capital to purchase a threshing machine. With the rest of this loan, she will buy more bean seeds for growing. In the future, she will expand her own farmland and grow more crops.

loans.use: to purchase a threshing machine and more bean seeds.

loans.name: Kea's Group

texts.en:
Kea is a 55-year-old mother of five children, four of whom are dependents while the fifth child works in Thailand. Two children are still in school. To make a living and feed her family in a rural area of Moung Russey District, Kea has been farming for more than 12 years on her rice field. 

Kea has been with VisionFund since 2010. And now Kea and two members in her group are requesting a loan from VisionFund. She will use this loan to buy fertilizer for her rice field. With this loan, she hopes to increase her crop yield and earn more income to build some savings for her children and also to keep her children in school.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer for her rice field.

loans.name: Rajab

texts.ru: Раджаб имеет большую семью. Он трудолюбивый и добросовестный человек. Раджаб женат, и отец шестерых детей. Ради обеспечения своих детей он начал свой бизнес и более четырех лет  занимается купле- продажей книг, канцтоваров, бижутерии и парфюмерии. Вначале он продавал только бижутерию, а постепенно добавил другие виды товаров. Его лавка находится возле центрального рынка, где много людей и они часто посещают его лавку. Раджаб хочет расширить свой бизнес и увеличить ассортимент товара. С этой целью он запрашивает займ в размере 5000 Сомони.
texts.en: Rajab has a large family.  He is a hardworking and conscientious person.  Rajab is married and is a father of six children.  He started his business in order to provide for his children and has been involved in buying and selling books, office supplies, jewelry and perfumes for over four years.  At fist, he only sold jewelry and then gradually added other types of goods.  His store is located near the central market, where there is a lot of people, who also often visit his store.  Rajab wants to grow his business and expand his merchandise selection.  This is why he is requesting this loan in the sum of 5000 Somoni.

loans.use: to expand merchandise selection

loans.name: Wariti Group

texts.fr:
Justine est présidente du groupe de crédit  wariti, cliente de l’IMF Hekima au 6e cycle, veuve, âgée de 38 ans, mère de six enfants qui vont tous à l’école mais un parmi les six souffre d’un handicap physique. . 
Elle a commencé son petit commerce en 2006 lors de la mort de son mari.  Elle vend des chaises plastiques et le jus de marque TAKENGO qu’on produit localement.    
Elle souhaite obtenir plus des crédits pour accroitre son chiffre d’affaire et  construire une maison en matériaux durable pour sa famille. 
Le groupe WARITI est composé de 19 membres.
texts.en:
Justine is the leader of Wariti Group, which counts 19 members. She's 38 years old, a widow, and the mother of six school-attending children. One of them suffers from a physical disability. 

With her group, Justine is seeking his sixth loan from Kiva's partner, MFI Hekima. She started her small business in 2006 when her husband died. She sells plastic chairs and TAKENGO, a locally made juice brand.

She would like a new loan to bolster her revenue and build a house out of durable materials for his family.

loans.use: to buy plastic chairs and boxes of TAKENGO (locally made juice)

location.country: The Democratic Republic of the Congo

loans.name: Mujeres Dinámicas Group

texts.es:
El grupo lleva el nombre de MUJERES DINAMICAS nombre elegido por las 10 mujeres que hacen parte de este comité de Mujeres de la Fundación Paraguaya, quienes viven en la ciudad de Villa Ygatimi. Actualmente se encuentran en el primer ciclo del programa de mujeres emprendedoras de la fundación, pero comentan que se encuentran con mucho entusiasmo para seguir con los demás ciclos.
Una de las miembros es la señora Gloria, quien trabaja en la cría de gallinas, comenta que es un trabajo muy lindo y que le encanta. Gracias a esto ella puede salir adelante en sus proyectos, pues esto le genera los ingresos necesarios. Le gustaría seguir creciendo y algún día tener un local donde vender sus pollos.
Ella solicita el crédito para que por medio de este pueda seguir creciendo, pues quiere comprar más gallinas para la cría y luego venderlas. Agradece por esta oportunidad que se le da, pues es muy importante para ella y las otras miembros.
texts.en:
The name of the Mujeres Dinámicas group was chosen by the ten women who make up this Fundación Paraguaya communal bank of women, who live in the city of Villa Ygatimi.  They are currently in the first loan cycle of the Fundación's program for women entrepreneurs, but they say they're very enthusiastic about continuing with the other cycles.

One of the members is Gloria, who works raising chickens.  She says it's a wonderful job and she loves it.  Thanks to this she can get ahead in her projects, since this generates the necessary income for her.  She would like to continue growing and one day have a place to sell her chickens.

She is requesting the loan so that she can continue to grow, since she wants to buy more chickens to raise and later sell.  She is grateful for this opportunity that is being given to her, since it's very important for her and the other members.

loans.use: to buy chickens to raise and later sell.

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 50-year-old married woman with three children between the ages of 22 and 28. All of them are in school. She has had a business of selling charcoal in Buluk, South Sudan for four years.

Mary requested this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal to sell
